I think if you had caught this, it may have given you pause, but this is an error that even someone that speaks nearly perfect English could make. üë©‚Äçüéì(although I guess it depends on how pedantic the recipient is)  I personally try not to respond to anything that comes from anything that looks official, but instead reach out on my own through their website and then take it from there. In an alternate universe jim browning is hired by the scammer and we all lose all our accounts and info
Very strange that youtube tried to tell you that your account was unrecoverable-because if that truly was the case, that would just be... really bad design? Like, there are a lot of different reasons why a channel might get deleted against the wishes of the channel owner-maybe the account was hacked, maybe the owner got phished, maybe the owner left their google account logged in on a computer that someone else had access too, and even if the owner was the one that deleted the account there are a lot of reasons why they might want to reverse it-for example, maybe they were the victim of a social engineering scam like this one! Since youtube wouldn't have any way to know if any of these were the case until the channel owner reached out, it would be good practice to keep deleted channels backed up for a period of time just in case-and indeed, it appears that youtube does do this, as they were able to restore your channel (and I believe there have been other similar situations before where they've restored channels).
It takes a great deal of courage, for someone like you, to tell the story publicly ...

When I used to investigate fraud for a bank, fraudsters would often be angling for feedback on why their scam had been unsuccessful. I would never give them anything, if they are educated on their weaknesses they only refine their scam or even change their strategy to something less predictable thus resulting in further losses you would otherwise be able to mitigate. I appreciate it must be difficult to balance what is useful insight and engaging content for viewers against that risk though.

I'm a little baffled you fell for this, given the grammar and capitalisation errors, not to mention the tone. They're trying to force you to click a link, THEREFORE you do not. You confirm via a different medium, and if you cannot, you ignore the message. It's the same for any interaction with a human : if they're trying to contact you, they want something, and if a human wants something, they're going to go as far as they need to, to take it from you. Sure it's easier to just trust blindly, but that's how they get you. Never, ever, EVER, trust a human.

Idk how you fell for this. Any entry level employee at my company would have seen this as phishing. There is simple and immediately obvious issues with the grammar. There is a missing period at the end of the first sentence. The second "sentence" starts in the middle of the last one. "Adsense" is wrong it's AdSense. Behavior is spelt without the "our" ending despite you being in the UK and likely having your settings set to UK English. Idk how you fell for this, but you aren't as smart as people think you are.

Not really Youtube but rather my Google account. One day I couldn't log into my account and I panicked. I'm pretty sure at that time I only had the phone verification and the email verification and that's it. Google logged out on my phone and I checked ALL of my devices that had my Youtube/Google/etc. logged in on it, and none of them were still logged in. I was so NEAR to having to start all over on a new Google account, but luckily for whatever reason, some app still had me logged on my phone and I was able to reset everything from there. This goes as a lesson to everyone, please, I'm literally begging you, PLEASE use all of the available 2 factor authentications. Don't have a phone number that can verify? Simple, have a trusted family member or friend that you can readily send the request to and receive the code. Make another gmail account and hook it up your main account in case you can't login there and can verify the code on the other account. Use ALL available 2 factor authentication incase another fails. I can't bare to see people on r/gmail or whatever losing precious memories and everything and Google doing jack crap about it. I really wanted to spread more awareness about this so such a preventable case doesn't ruin a person's day.

I've liked your content over the years but I can't help but feel a small amount of poetic justice to what happened ahahah
Thinking 2FA will save you is really faulty line of thinking. I had a sleazy Friday night and I got temporarily scammed out of my FFXIV game account that HAD 2FA enabled. I clicked a link, then closed the website that opened. I then started typing the link manually and I didn't realise that chrome's history gave me the same link I closed. Sleazy night, all right! I then proceeded to log in on forums that belong to scammers, providing both my password and 2FA. Now, my password manager didn't suggest a password, but 2 factors played key role here. First, final fantasy XIV has shitton of domains, subdomains, so in the past I had to add extra urls to password manager entry... Since it was a domain I typed 'myself', it didn't ring any alarm bells. and secondly, the domain has an excellent typo in it, once I sorted out everything, I came back to the url and I had to scan it with my eyes three times to see the unbelievable part.  Now, this 2FA was really time sensitive, because plenty of times when I'd type stuff from my 2FA on my phone into the game window, it would be already out of date! But scammers were able to use 2FA from fake-forum form and log in game as me, they were either very lucky or had some automation in place. They also logged into account management on website.   The moment they logged in game, I was logged out and well, it clicked that I was scammed. The password was reset, which I noticed when I tried to log back in - in game and into account management on the website.  I started password recovery and I got the email, quickly resetting password, and logging in, which logged scammers out. I lost control of my account for about 5 minutes, but my character was already moved to a different location and by the looks of it, I was sending more phishing links to other players (as they started replying when I logged in, so I told them to not open the link, clear history and never trust links sent via dms...).   Luckily, access to critical account information was gated with birth date question. Only once you get through birth date, you then can change email address... but only if you know my mother's maiden name, it's something around the lines of 7T25wzMBwq9UA356zRtTgj2A8.   Had this game service not have extra security on critical account features, my account would have been a goner WITH 2FA enabled. One of the reasons I fell for this (aside from sleazy Friday night!) was because I was lulled into false sense of security because I had 2FA. I would normally be a bit hesitant to use 2FA on a game account, as it's just a faff, but Square Enix gives you free teleport location if you have 2FA enabled, and this is something I can't pass on, so great great incentive from SE!  For the record, I consider myself a security conscious person, password manager for everything and 2fa whereever possible, and even my bank has something like 2yUMQRF88WSxv5miBicsyBTqq for my mother's maiden name. I think my childhood dog's name is hUr4pkMUJAui5TFJPZAN8hcFM - the bank employee tried to contest my answers once, but stopped resisting after I asked her "are you saying my dog can't be named hUr4pkMUJAui5TFJPZAN8hcFM?!".   Ever since it happened to me, I proudly tell the story how I was temporarily phished out of my most precious game account to all of my friends and family, which is even more powerful when I'm considered the "tech wizard" (and I'm not, but for those people I probably am).
A learning lesson. so sad-I'm sorry they did this to you.

Coincidence is probably the biggest factor here. I think I dodged a scam from "Internet  Service Provider A" because I was having a stressful day. I'd just switched to ISP B from ISP A, and had had a call from the genuine ISP A trying to keep my custom, but couldn't match the price I was getting, or the speed. I thought they'd called back for a second attempt at first, but after a few minutes I was suspicious. I'd had a stressful day and was frankly pissed off at the 2nd attempt so I wasn't being very forgiving. Then the guy said there was no way for them to slow down the connection (I think he'd offered me a speed that wasn't possible with my infrastructure), and when I pointed out throttling was a thing he got unreasonably pissed off... then I figured that a genuine call wouldn't involve a temper tantrum, so hung up. If I hadn't been at work I might have played with him a bit longer.

Honestly I was almost scammed into something the other day. I was expecting to be contacted for a job opportunity anyway, so when I get a WhatsApp message saying they have an opportunity for me I went along with it for a bit. Got bounced between a couple different accounts and the website and accounts were claiming to be from a real company. Slowly it dawned on me that this was a scam as they didn't ask for any details on myself to get started, the job itself was basically cookie clicker, and the website had weird spelling errors. After some research it finally clocked, so I asked them some questions about how they thought this job ACTUALLY was supposed to work, to which they just claimed it did. Then blocked and reported their numbers and called it a day. Coincidence really is a powerful tool

Email spoofing is when an attacker uses a fake email address with the domain of a legitimate website. This is possible because domain verification is not built into the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP), the protocol that email is built on.  <- Absolutely scary how weak this line of defense is

I appreciate you recognizing your own mistake and sharing it on your channel. Your mistake as you might know was avoidable though. I am only mentioning it for others, since it was not mentioned in your video. When an e-mail has anything to do with something regarding your account, money or whatever else. Never click on a link, always logon to your account and go from there. This way you can avoid simple mistakes as not seeing the support email domain, or anything else.

if only you could lay out all the details for us where tech companies have created the vulnerabilities that help arm thieves. For example third party info capture, the fact devices require you to log in with an email that can be tracked to identify you. Rather than allow you to be anonymous. There's keystroke detection, built into your system so when they get into this data they'll know literally every action that you've done. Also why do I pay for a product that yes can process more than before and it costs more compared to  before but does little in the way compared in advancements, and maybe that's because your computing power goes to background collection of data and transmission supporting the company you bought it from, every time you type a letter it doubles the bit usage alone to store it. Yes you're financing the technology within your purchase of a product to support their collection of data. This data collection is meant to make life more convenient. Just goes to show that nobody is immune to scams -- even people who very clearly know their stuff can get tricked.  It doesn't matter how wise or vigilant you are, there will be moments where you are not investing 100% of your attention into discerning scams from genuine correspondence.
One should never let his guard down no matter how good a person is, because even an idiot given the right moment can scam.

I'm very late to this video, but I have worked in IT help desk for a year and a half now and have had to do phishing training several times as a natural part of that. The downfall of training for things like phishing is that it touches on common things like spelling errors, bad links, a sense of urgency, etc. However it doesn't cover how every so often the stars align just so, and you miss one little detail, or else happen to have a scammer that is at least skilled in ctrl+c ctrl+v and has a good script.

This is absolutely a case where YouTube / Google did half the work. Their UI/UX is horrendous and make the site's (and really all of their recent apps) functionality vague, confusing, and impossible to navigate - which opens the door for bad actors to come in and take advantage of that confusion.
It's probably easy to fall for when you're actually in that situation, since you're maybe panicking a bit. Truly, great kudos for sharing your own mistakes. Getting scammed easily makes you feel humiliated, and it lessens the shame knowing that even people like you Jim can indeed fall for it. Like you said, it can happen to anybody. I think a good rule to do as a precaution, -even when not being suspicious, is to thank for the info you're given and say you'll get back to them later during the day to solve it. That way you are contacting the company yourself
I suspect the other Jim was offered that new domain name for a fee, and paid it.
It is difficult to notice these types of scams because they are usually designed around the idea of putting you into a high stress situation. But that is usually a good indicator that you are being scammed. If you are stressed and feeling rushed to get things done, it is important to take a step back and realize that there is no such thing as a situation where you should ever feel rushed. Everything can be handled at a later time, whether hours or even a day or two later. When someone is trying to rush you, always get into the habit of realizing that there is always going to be time to get it done and train yourself to slow down and investigate the situation more. I'm not saying that everyone who tries to rush you is trying to scam you, but it is definitely a good indicator that you are being tricked into doing something.

These scammers are getting smarter and more sophisticated with their techniques. We need to adapt and get smarter as well. I am glad you have learned how this method of scam works. It's unfortunate that your Channel was "somewhat compromised" in the process BUT the pos thing about it is that you learned / we learned how sophisticated these scammers are getting and gained more knowledge of their techniques.   This just triggered a new awareness to me. From now on I'm JUST GOING TO IGNORE ALL emails about anything dealing with accounts or any emails about anything regardless of if it is legitimate or not!! And If I receive one that looks legitimate, then I'll contact the company directly and not take a risk on clicking or calling any numbers that they provide me EVEN IF THEY ARE LEGIT. It's gone to this as scammers had found ways to be the actual legitimate companies by hijacking their IP or websites.    It's crazy bc, I actually did a dark web scan for my personal info using one of my credit score company (they offered a free scan as their company was compromised a few yrs back) and My personal EMAIL, both first and last name, my Cell #, and some of my old passwords, was actually found in the dark web being sold. And I am one of those guys who is very careful with their sensitive data, I guess I was not careful enough as they have my info.   I watch A LOT OF Trilogy media, IRL rosie, Scamers paybak, and now I've subed to this channel in hopes to educate myself, keep up to date with the new scams being used out on the web, and prevent from getting scammed in the future.

I've been scammed twice.   Once was my fault - I entered all my details into an online form.   The second happened when I wasn't sent the second of the two factor authentication, to confirm. Yes, I had changed all my details. I still have no idea how that one went ahead.   Both times I got my account back. This wasn't for YouTube.

Your content and data was not in fact deleted.  A common safeguard is to have a field in the database that is a "Delete" flag, and when true the content/data is not shown or rendered in the browser.  The recovery team would simply go through their databases/tables of your channel and update that field.
I hope one day you play a recording of my conversation with a Medicare or life insurance scammer. I get about 18 calls a day, I‚Äôve began to answer with this. teree maan kee choot mein haathee kee Soond. Tends to irratate them pretty well. üòÇ
2:30 I fell for this kind of coincidental thing once. I'm the kind of person who rarely orders anything off of the internet and had never used vinted or shipped through Hermes before. So when, a week after ordering my first item off vinted through hermes, I got a text from 'hermes' telling me that they'd tried to deliver my item but had missed me, I believed it. After all, I was out that day at comic-con, there was no guarantee that any on my housemates were home, and  I had not clue what the usual protocol was for vinted or hermes. For all I knew, this was legitimate but just not something I'd encountered before.   I filled in the form on the link they sent, which asked for my card for the late fee (something I'd had also had reason to believe because I've had to pay for legitimate post related things online before) and it was only the next day when vinted refunded me for my item (which the sender never sent, so the order was cancelled) that I realised I'd been had. Fortunately, my card information had not been used and I was able to freeze and cancel the card before anything untoward could happen but it really was a reality check as I had previously thought myself too clever to fall for a scam. Coincidence is indeed a dangerous weapon in the hands of a scammer.

I work in enterprise IT and a lot of new people wonder why we are so silo'd and have such strange seeming processes to do simple things. It's because of this. Social engineering can unseat even the most scrupulous security freak and the only defense is to have power segregated and divided into multiple hands that don't work closely with each other.

I wanted to take a second to say thank you. Because i listen to you i understand what a scam call looks like and sounds like. About 4 months ago I raised $6,000 for a friends family. He died from a sudden heart attack and the family needed some financial help.  The money was in my PayPal and i wanted to transfer it into a GoFundMe account.  I was having trouble doing so and i Googled the number for PayPal.  The problem was the number that came up wasn't PayPal but a scammer.  After a few short minutes on the phone i quickly realized what was happening.  I called out the scammer. He got mad and started yelling at me.   Later i found PayPals actual number. In the end PayPal told me they didn't support large sums of money being transferred into Go Fund Me because of scams. Lol
I'm a software developer who's quite conscious about security topics, but I've fallen for social engineering once, letting someone gain access to a political Twitter account I was controlling. It was quite a motivated person who targeted me specifically due to being political enemies...   The "funny" thing is, while I was easily able to recover the account, it then became completely impossible to log in to due to what seemed to be a really stupid bug in Twitter. No matter what I did, it kept asking for some kind of verification. Contacted Twitter support countless times, but no dice. They're really terrible. After a year or so the bug was fixed and I was able to log in again. So stupid. Bugged mega-corporation software was the real problem all along. :-P

I'm skeptical of 2FA myself. I recently had an attempt on my Facebook which is secured with 2FA. I had noticed a notification pop up on my phone saying that my friend request I sent out was approved. I didn't send any friend request, so I immediately checked it out, within seconds of seeing it.  Some random person I've never heard of accepted a request. I blocked the person and went to check the security page. I noticed on the active devices that my account was logged into a device from (if I can remember) Lebanon. Well, I pushed that off the list, reset my password and told Facebook to logout of every other device.  I'm not sure how that managed to happen but prior to this there was a red flag on my Google account, specifically Google Backup and Sync. The account wasn't compromised as far as I could tell. No nefarious logins, no strange activity, but the Google security was pretty sure I needed to review things. Regardless I did the whole gambit of changing the password and all that, twice, just to make sure.  Not sure if those were related in any way, but it was strange they managed to get around 2FA on Facebook, and past the logging in from an unknown machine. I still managed to stop it within 2 minutes of the notification popping up.
I'm sure this works on some people but there's no way he's going to keep this up without getting caught.  He's not even smart enough not to connect to the internet to talk to someone he just scammed without using a proxy or VPN.  It looks like he may have  just used his own home fiber internet service, given the info that IP shows.  Not a good idea if you're trying to internationally extort money out of someone.  Turkish prisons are not a fun time.

One thing is for sure, I don't click on links even if it was sent by the FBI or MI5, if I get an email concerning anything, I always call the business directly, you can get these information from their websites directly (this means I don't call numbers in the emails). I don't pick up calls on my land line and I don't picks up calls from numbers that are not saved on my phone. I don't use my banks cards in stores or online but I have cards like Revolut which I put a minimum of ¬£20 which regards I don't use in any store or website, only those I believe are verified.  Regards of all these anyone could get scammed but taking these steps helps reduce the chances. 13:40  *ANSWER* *pretty simple trick.* You can change anything in a web page using chrome Devloper tool.  Devloper Tool  allow you to change any of html elements  in a web  page. (EX: headings,size, height, width, colour, fonts,tags etc)        *To open the developer tool in Google Chrome, open the Chrome Menu in the upper-right-hand corner of the browser window and select More Tools > Developer Tools. You can also use Option + ‚åò + J (on macOS), or Shift + CTRL + J (on Windows/Linux).*

I think it's worth noting that any email can claim to come from any domain. The reply-to address is nothing but a text field set by the sender, and it is stupidly easy to forge. Viewing the email's source info can help determine its veracity, but as this video demonstrates, even that isn't foolproof.   The best thing you can do when you get a message like this, demanding "immediate action or such-and-such service will be suspended," is to go straight to the service's website. Do not trust the links in the email even if they look completely legit.

I also had the "coincidence" thing happen to me. I got a call (not from India, but from Florida) informing me that I had an outstanding bill for blood work done at a lab. Both my wife & I had had blood tests just s month or 2 before (there's the coincidence). I told them I would check on it. They called back later when I was out and talked to my wife. She told them that we hadn't received any bill notification. The scammer told her that if she didn't settle the matter over the phone that the bill would reflect on our credit score. Now, here's another coincidence: we have a credit score of 850. It's the highest issued and we're quite proud of it. So...my wife caved in and gave up $300 via her debit card. Later, we called the bank's fraud department and got them on a conference call with the scammers. They had an answer for every questions, but in the end refunded our money back to the bank. A very enlightening experience. Keep 'em coming, Jim!

Jim Browning, to me the lesson learned is not that absolutely anyone can be scammed, that's a given to me, but rather just how does the scammer go about scamming. So true to form you let yourself be scammed which is the way you work, but you also learned how they do it. So I think its a win and I encourage you in your fight against scammers as they become more knowledgeable and technical at conducting this crime.

If anyone out there ever gets an email asking you to do something because of an issue.  Stop.  Do not click the links. Open up the actual site it is supposedly from and contact their support. Sorry to see this happened to you. Myself since the early days of internet, I have always been sceptical of any email I receive.  If I am presented with anything remotely genuine looking, I‚Äôll go to the support page of the actual company (in a fresh window), or call their actual support number (from their actual web site that I typed myself) and verify.  It takes a bit longer but it is safer than clicking links in the emails. Never ever click those.
I recently got an email from Google that I thought was suspicious BUT I didn't click on any links in the email. i went to my account and tried to verify the details there. It turned out the email was genuine but I DON''T TRUST ANYTHING that comes via email. NEVER NEVER NEVER click on email links even if you think they are genuine, go to your account and check there for verification. The only links on email I will click are those that are asking me to verify an email address when I am opening an account somewhere. Even with those, if they don't come through almost immediately, I don't click on anything if they turn up later.
Believe me, I know coincidences. We had to take our Suburban in to a certified dealership because our regular mechanic couldn't figure out what was wrong with our car. After a few days, they confirmed that both airbag sensors on the Suburban had to be replaced and it would cost us $1200. After that call, a day or two later, I got a call offering to give me extended warranty service on our Suburban. I figured that our repair triggered something in a system somewhere. So, not thinking anything else about it, I figured to go ahead and get registered so that we'd be covered for the next major repair. A few months later, we got a letter in regards to our warranty service being upgraded. This is where the scam fell apart. I saw the previous warranty service and the charge on our credit card had a different name from the one on the upgrade letter. They just told us to cancel the old one. Well, I call up the other company and, after talking to a rather rude person, they told me that the other service was a scam. Eventually, I put two and two together and determined that both companies were a scam. Fortunately, I explained the situation to our credit card company and they refunded us the fraud charges.

This is an excellent point Jim makes. I work in Cybersecurity and there is a constant battle about how much we should train end users or depend on them to stop potential attacks. Awareness is great and can help prevent a larger overall number of issues, but we still need to make sure there are good procedure and products in place. CEOs get tricked, Exec Admins get tricked, even CISOs get tricked. Especially now in this crazy hybrid world we live in where everyone is stressed and working as hard as they can. Have some additional empathy and build a culture where it is ok to pause for a moment and double check if something seems legitimate. Also, I bet in this case if Youtube had a responsive account management style for content creators I am sure Jim could have contacted a named rep at Youtube when this message first initially came up.

This may be a flawed way of going about things (because I‚Äôm not an expert by any means) but many times when I receive electronic correspondance from YouTube, Google, or another business I have an account with and they‚Äôre emailing me about an issue with said account, I will leave the email and go to their site which I know to be credible and start a correspondance with them myself through their support links. I then tell them about the email I received and ask them about the issue. That way, I am more certain that anyone I speak with in that message chain is credible. Like I said, it may not be the best way of dealing with things like this but it makes me more comfortable just going to the credible source myself and opening up dialogue with them.

Could you please look into the weird ‚Äògoodbye‚Äô calls that have been going around for the last 10+ years and have recently got a lot more prominent? If you‚Äôre not familiar with them a mobile number from your country calls (for me once a day at different times and changing the number by a few digits every few days) and when answered there is nothing but silence for a few seconds but when you say hello an automated voice just says goodbye and hangs straight up.   It‚Äôs quite spooky and there‚Äôs a few theories kicking around in forums dating back all the way to before 2010 with exactly the same details of the call if you could take a look it could make for an interesting discovery

Some years ago my Windows XP crashed. As I cursed and began troubleshooting I got a call (within 10 seconds of the crash). It was a "Microsoft Support Technician" saying that something was wrong with my Windows computer. Can you imagine that coincidence?!  It took my mind 20-30 seconds to process this. There's a new Fedex scam going around where they're saying that your packaged couldn't be delivered for some bs reason, and charge a $2 fee, and then take out as much as they can. He missed the #1 rule of not falling for any of these scams, THE biggest alarm bell should always be why do they need you to do this on the user end?  If there was truly an issue and you were speaking to a YouTube technician they would have the ability to do all of these things from their side. The Amazon refund scam is obviously a scam because Amazon don‚Äôt need you to do anything online in order to cancel an account or send you a refund. Just like if there‚Äôs a problem with someone ‚Äòhacking‚Äô your internet connection your isp can look into/resolve it without needing you to login to your computer. Okay so as a linguistics maniac, just reading the first chat they sent put me off. Here's why: 1. "Please note that we have noticed that you have [...]" Putting 'that' twice in the same sentence so close to each other is a big no-no if you want your text to sound professional and roll off the tongue nicely. They should've started their sentence  at "we". 2. They indicate that there is a duplicate AdSense account, but show no proof of this. They should cite the name of the account or have a link somewhere here. And the first S in AdSense should be capitalised. 3. "[...]and as a result We will permanently [...]"  Wtf was that? They're just gonna skip a line and put a capital letter in the middle of a sentence where a comma should be? NO. EW. 4. "Try chat" should be in quotes. 5. "[...]unintended behavior" Where's the period? Also, that's just a really weird choice of words. 6. "We are waiting for your reply" Again, no period. And it's not signed, wtf? Whoever wrote this has a really slippery grasp of punctuation and professionalism. The wording here also indicates that you cannot opt out of contacting them. Red flags everywhere for me.  Really glad you got your account back! :)
It was a blessing in disguise. You were able to get your channel back plus make this video to make other people aware

I missed a single line of misspelling within the email.  Felt so embarrassed after regardless of the coincidence. Unfortunately, 2SA is useless. Like Facebook, you can setup the 2SA with different methods like phone text message, google code, mail, etc.. But if you can't verify the 2SA, you or the hacker in this situation, can choose another 2SA method to use. He just have to use your password to add a 2SA method to the account. Then once he add ex: 2SA: send a code by text, he will receive it on his phone since he added his phone as the new 2SA method. So 2SA is just useless in every way if they have your password!

A lot the people you condemn are very desperate and have no good options to make a living, but you do a pile of great work to expose how this criminality works so that we all understand, so ‚ù§Ô∏è for that.  Here's what I said to my people when I posted this video on my social media: This is how all scammers work.  It doesn't matter if they're on the TV or internet, it doesn't matter if they're famous, rich, or the president.  The guy that was got in this case was a famous, professional hunter of scammers.  He made the same mistake everyone makes, whether someone is confronted by a poor man who's desperate to feed his children, or an intelligence agent with a gun to their head trying to destroy their country, they always cave to FEAR.  "We will permanently suspend your YouTube account."  That line made him poop his pants.  If they suspended his account, he would lose hundreds of thousands of dollars.  Everything he did after that was a mistake, because he was drunk with fear.  Fear is the single most destructive force in the human world.  NEVER make big decisions based on fear ‚ù§Ô∏è

So I'm not sure if anyone has mentioned this yet, but, focusing on the mail from chat-noreply@google.com, I realize that this is a legit email from google their chat system. So essentially the initial mail just mentions that some random person (named YouTube Support) has sent a message to you on their chat platform.  So to all of those that claim "people can impersonate mails from Google", this is actually untrue. All that has happened with this email is a notification that you should check up on your chat to check up on messages. This would be exactly the same if someone else has sent a message through chat.
I had a similar situation like this but via Steam. I think it was 2 years ago a "friend" in Steam told me that he accidentally and wrongly reported my account for having a "dirty" inventory specifically my Team Fortress 2 items and that the Steam moderators will delete my account permanently if i don't appeal my innocence.  So i contacted the moderator he linked to me to have a chat about my account. The "moderator" told me that he was legit and he wanted me to "borrow" all my items to him so that he can verify them and check to see if they are truly clean or not.  He sent the trade offer, i foolishly accepted, went to my phone and ready to confirm the trade (Steam's trading security procedure) but before i pressed confirm i went a on a quick Google search of Steam's official moderators and his name just wasn't there. At that point, i knew what was going on so i called him out for being a fakey. It turns out, my "friend" was the scammer all along.

Good Rule of Thumb here:   Big Corporation don't care about you, your problems, nor any issues on your channel...  unless it is majorly affecting THEIR money that THEY'RE making. Big Corporation will NEVER send you a "hey we need to fix this problem that is only affecting YOU."   THEY...  DO NOT...  CARE.   If you get an email that basically says "hey your channel is having this problem, we need to fix it, click this thing".  It's fake.

The scammer didn't send you an email. They sent you a message on Google Chat (was Hangouts) and then it was left unread so Google sent you an email to remind you to check the message. I don't want to sound like a dick, but you fell for a social engineering scam.

This is so bad on so many levels. But this is _entirely_ google's fault. They allowed completely random people to send emails from their domain name.   Someone was clever enough to do the scam once, and that means it's going to spread of thousands of other Google related scams. And they deal with _way_ more sensitive stuff than just individual YouTube channels.  What happens when people start stealing _actual gmail accounts?_ That opens the door up to basically every account a person owns. Even bank accounts, if the victim is really unlucky.

Time and time again you see this in movies, TV, comics, and stories, but it's passed off as a trope.  It's far more likely that someone will be convinced to willingly give their password to someone than for a "hacker" to break into the system and steal it. This wasn't random. I think you were targeted based on your content (not an original thought, I'm sure).
If the attacker was really dedicated, they could have possibly SIM swapped you after getting your password. This is an attack where they call your cell phone provider pretending to be you (they can call each if they don‚Äôt know which you use) and scam the service tech into swapping the phone number to a new device. If successful, they may be able to have the 2FA (2SA as Jim says) token texted to THEIR phone since it temporarily has your number until you and the cell provider realize what happened.
It takes a lot of humility to be doing what you do and admit to being scammed. I think even more of you now sir!

Fantastic video, always sobering to realise even tech professionals get scammed. We often don't get to hear of major scams, as people are embarrassed that despite knowing better, they fell for a convincing con and lost a lot of money, despite thinking they had done due diligence.
These scorched earth scams can be particularly hard to spot because there is no direct way a scammer can profit - until he asked for the money. So it is understandable that one doesn't recognize it. What would have saved me here, is that I never click on links in mails, I always browse to the sites by myself and this is imho one of the most important advice to give people: Don't click on links, always navigate to your accounts yourself.
First things first- YouTube will never Contact you by mail which you Provide in your About Section, rather by your Actual Mail Address. Note: Never Share your Actual Channel Mail with Anyone. For business Purposes, always Use a Secondary Mail ID

My grandmother fell for one of those very standard scams, the 'give me access to your pc' kind of things. She came down, saying 'the nice man from microsoft is helping me but I need you to deal with it' and, having just woken up and knowing how she can have trouble with it, I didn't put two and two together. It wasn't until a bit later, as they were rooting around her pc, that I called up a friend and they very helpfully woke me up by explaining how I was being a complete moron. Turned off the internet, had to go through a ton of hoops, but eventually took care of things. This was during my first year of studying in a cyber security degree, so as you can imagine it's an embarrassing moment for me but a very important one as well that I will definitely do my best to learn from.  Point of this whole thing, Jim's right, anyone can be caught up in a scam. Some easier than others, but if the dominos fall in the right way even an expert (or someone learning to become an expert) can make a very basic oopsie.

When I was practicing martial arts my masters told me that even a  grandmaster could be killed by a common thug if they are attacked when they are distracted.  In fact, one of my masters told us how he got stabbed by a mugger once. He was walking home and as he turned the corner there was suddenly a guy in front of him and he felt a punch on his stomach. The element of surprise let the un-trained thug stab him before he was able to react. Now, the moment after the thug had his elbow and knee shattered, but that didn't change the fact that he stabbed the master first. Luckily the injury wasn't serious and he recovered fully, but he could have easily been killed there, simply because his attention waned just in the wrong moment. So the lesson is the same as here: No matter how good and experienced we get, we are still just humans and are not infallible.

I learned the coincidence lesson a few years ago.  I purchased somethingn off ebay and got a fake email about 5 mins later saying there was a problem with my ebay account.  I thought I knew what was wrong so clicked the link in the email without checking. In your assessment of what you should have done, you missed the most important thing to do which is true of all scams where they contact you first:  don't have the conversation they initiated. Break the conversation, find the legitimate contact channel for the company and verify the claims with them.  Same as when someone from the bank/other company unexpectedly calls you about your account. If you had done that, the whole thing would have been avoided (but of course as you say, you were distracted and we're only human.. and hindsight is 20/20 :) ).

Glad you got your channel back! Best rule of thumb, if you get a support request from a company, especially with something of high value (like bank account), contact the company via their website's support. Internal links aren't always easy to spot the re-directs and false domains.

@Jim Browning, it‚Äôs possible to proxy a google login page such that you are tricked to login and enter you 2fa token and the attacker obtains it‚Ä¶ what makes this convincing is that the victim is successfully logged into their account and therefore does not feel threatened.. meanwhile an attacker has placed a system in the middle of the connection and is harvesting credentials and cookies to enable stealing a session to YouTube (or which ever service they are proxying),  The attack basically only requires the victim to click on a link.. lucky scammers typically aren‚Äôt so tech savvy.. let me know if you would like a demo of this method (using a burner account üòÖ).

I still feel awful for falling for a scam over a year ago. I was threatened that my steam account would be deleted and took it seriously as I've been banned on steam before. They simply wanted a code and to verify that my card wasn't fraudulent (coincidentally I had a problem with my card at the same time so it was believable.) That code was enough to get access to my entire account and they 'locked' it by making it private. I honestly want to meet those fuckers in person so I can punch them in the face. Pure evil. Steam support are nearly just as bad for letting a scam like this happen. It was because of steam support falsely banning me in the past that made me feel so scared in the first place. Furthermore, I don't think they even knew my password, they managed to get in simply with that code. Fucking what's the point of a fucking password anymore.

Jim I feel for you but I also think this needed to happen to you as this was red flags on top of red flags on top of red flags. A google chat message is never going to be the official communication channel for something like this, ever. Being from Google.com instead of youtube should've been red flag number one. Sure Google owns youtube but their support queries are via Youtube as are all of their communications. The threat of permanent suspension and the way that was worded in such a dire manner to illicit immediate action was also a red flag. Any panic inducing email should first trigger, "OK I'm ready to act without thinking, could this be phishing?" The casing in the chat was also a dead give away. Also, I'm sort of shocked you went along with "Are you using a PC?" didn't that trigger some kind of unsettled ironic feeling given your background with these scammers? Why does using a PC matter to Google? Is Youtube different on a Mac? I know you were kicking yourself in hindsight but sometimes I think we need to feel the heat of the flame to be reminded that fire is real. You're a hero to your audience but a target to these guys, you've gotta have a more paranoid mindset around your jewels, these guys are out to get you!

1:12 they didn't so much "send emails from that domain" or "set their from address" as stated -- This is a user, on Google Chat that has the display name "YouTube Support" and after attempting to message you they relied on the email being generated from the Google Chat service to you.  The email you received passed all the checks because it (the email) wasn't spoofed at all, the email was generated on Google's servers and sent by Google as a notification <somebody> messaged you.   Anybody that messages you should result in an email in the same format, from the same address being sent to you -- the things that change are the name it shows you, and the message you missed.

Welcome to why I reply to all unknown users that send me emails, DMs, etc with "Is this a bot?" "Are you trying to scam me?" and "Are you trying to steal my account?" Usually the very first reply after is enough but if they then try to get you to click links, know they are likely a scammer BUT we all have friends that send us links and sometimes scammers have gotten hold of friend accounts so know your freinds and if they are acting strange just point-blank them one of the above questions. Scammers rarely respond well to instantly getting called out (phone scammer just hang up but messaging scams will often try a bit to get you to do it anyway.

I'm sorry this happened to you and I am glad you are sharing your experience. For anyone that may read this. NEVER click on a link provided in a e-mail unless you are expecting a specific link from a specific person. This is how every phishing scam works. They will try to scare and say that you need to log in to your account to verify information or something like that. The proper way to handle a situation like this is to log in to your account from a browser(don't click the email link) Then you can see if the information in the e-mail is accurate. In this case if Jim had logged into his adsense account instead clicking on the link he would know that it was phishing e-mail because there would have been no communication on his dashboard.

12:20 The proper term is 2FA (2 factor authentication) or MFA (multi factor authentication). I wouldn't have guessed what "2-SA" means.
I think this is actually caused by a really poor UI in Youtube settings.  5:38 Shows the screenshot of the problematic UI. It first says that "currently connected channel will be deleted" and then follows the channel that's important to you *with no explanation why it's displayed at this position.*   Had there been label "THIS IS THE CONTENT THAT WILL BE DELETED:" I'm pretty sure this whole incident wouldn't happened.  The way the UI has been designed, it looks like you're going to *move* this content (170 videos and 3.3M subscribers) to another channel.

Yes bad timing or so to say good timing for scammers happens,  I had an issue with multiply accounts with Microsoft.  So I  tried to clean up the account myself and quickly found I couldn't do it, so I called Microsoft and tried to have them walk me through it.  We ran into some Issues and they gave me a case#  asked my phone# for disconnection and e-mail,  when the scammers called I assumed it was the real Microsoft and went into action to clear up this problem.  It was only when he ran the windows program and told me it was a virus is when started to catch on.  also he showed me the disabled programs and most them I had disabled.  Sadly yes I gave them access to my PC.  I cut the connection in time and no files were lost,  but that is when the scammers were relentless in trying to scam me.  Needles to say I  searched the internet and finally found help in the form of YouTube channels.  I watched many scam baiters harassing the scammers and knew right away this was over my ability.  I did find Scammer Payback totally by accident and to this day I am glad I did, this person and many others like him are doing us a great service.  Like you said and I have expressed this to many people any one can fall into a scam, especially when there are so many different scams out there  Thanks You for all you do Mr. Browning  and all other scam baiters as well

First, I am OLD. I have been "online" since the old BBS dayz (metered time, tying up a land line for hours), and I remember gasoline costing .08 cents a gallon. Yes, I am OLD. But this is yet another classic case of nuclear weapons, aka "just-because-you-can-doesn't-mean-you-should", namely the push to put everything online, make the end user do all the work while profits go up, usually under the guise of user's being "self-sufficient". Online services completely lack ANY telephone support. Nothing. If you're lucky to have a local site supporter, you may actually be able to walk in their office & talk to a human being. Now ANY contact is textual & most likely coming from another country that really doesn't take customer service seriously. So local employers are squeezed out of the market & customer service goes down. All because ya'll were hypnotized by the glamor ("Looker" tek) of the web. You have been assimilated. In closing, boycott "self-service" - give someone a job & relax while the station pumps your gas & the stores check your groceries out!

I've been scammed/almost scammed multiple times. The one I remember the best is when I almost lost my brand new Diablo 3 account. My dad bought Diablo 3 with Reaper of Souls for me so I could play with my friends and I got a weird message aboug something being wrong with my acc and I needed to log in to confirm it was me or something. I was 15 at the time, thought nothing of it, did it and continued playing. I didn't even have Blizzard's 2SA on. Next day, I couldn't log in. Thankfully I managed to recover my account that same day and set up 2SA. Also had my Steam account almost stolen twice, too.

Problem with the 2fa is somebody is still going to verify because chat will tell them it's part of the process. At that point it seems like google support sending out the 2fa and they will tell you to click 'yes it's me' to confirm and continue. If the scammer gets that far I'd say at least a 50% chance the person falls for authenticating 2fa...
The lesson here‚Ä¶don‚Äôt action anything from an email, text or call. Simply Google the official contact and that rarely goes wrong.

It seems like they didn't "hijack" a @google.com email, so much as Google sent you a real notification email about having a new message on their proprietary messaging service. It just so happened that this new message was masquerading as additional information from Google. The small print at the bottom specifies that this email represents a chat message from a user, which is meaningless if you didn't know having a Google account included being part of its messenger.

Scammers are getting revenge. I hope you get them Jim.
Over the past few months I've come across verified YouTube channels with 100k+ some even 1 million+ subscribers, who have zero videos but only a "live" stream about cryptocurrency. They renamed the channel to "Ripple XRP" and the live stream had some overhyped clickbait title about an impending XRP boom. Turned out it's an old video from a few years ago with the CEO Brad Garlinghouse of Ripple having an interview with Business Insiders. They edited the video to have a scroll banner at the bottom of the screen (where you'd usually see stock prices) and had message saying something like "Ripple CEO is doubling your tokens for the next few minutes only. Send any amount of XRP to wallet #XYZ and we will return double the amount". To have it directly in the video made it look more professional rather than as a video description. Quite an old Crypto scam but the way it was pulled off with a channel that had 100k or even 1 million+ subscribers, verified and a live stream that looked genuine, really made me look twice. I can only assume that someone's YouTube channel got hacked/scammed, they deleted all the videos, renamed it and put up that fake live stream. I guess this is one way to "monetize" from a stolen YouTube account. Even if the scammer just runs that fake live stream for a few minutes or hours, I am sure some people fell for it.

as you ought to know, the first thing most scammers will try to do is instill a sense of urgency to throw you off your game. Since your livelihood (or a significant chunk of it? I don't know how much you make) comes from your Google account/AdSense, I can totally understand why this worked on you. So what would you have done differently if you had noticed the red flag? That is, had you noticed they were trying to make you rush, how would you have proceeded? would you have completely ignored the email (despite the apparent threat to your income), or maybe tried to find out from Google's support forums whether it was legitimate?

13:35 if the image screenshot was sent to you via WhatsApp, you can see if the image has been compressed by increasing its contrast to the maximum. A PNG image does not have any artifacts but JPEG or V9 does. Now I don't know if JPEG and V9 COMPRESSION artifacts are the same. If it's V9, it's video thus coming from a YouTube video. If it's JPEG then it's a screenshot on PC if no artifacts are visible it is most certainly PNG or BMP which is definetly legit. I cannot check here because its your YouTube video. But you have the original picture.

The one time I fell for a spear phishing training at work was remarkably similar. The scary "the bureaucracy screwed you, and it's going to screw you even harder if you don't click this link" email is incredibly persuasive as it feeds into the existing expectations (bureaucracies are expected to screw up) and the worry shuts off the critical thinking part of your brain. There are all kinds of flags: The email lacks punctuation. There are run on sentences galore. The email is to "Hi" not "Hi <actual name>". The already mentioned chat email name. The sentences are awkwardly constructed "Please reply to us by clicking on Try Chat *there should be a period here* to contact us if you..."
In most cases they will say hi <username>. The scammer was probably lol when he got a channel about tech scams

He was expecting an issue because he swapped devices the day before, so he ignored some obvious warning signs (non-official-looking writing and non-youtube/google domain in the chat). It was very lucky timing on behalf of the scammer.

POV: *You're here from Timeworks*
"I'm YouTube" - scumbag scammer 2021
"Anyone can be scammed". Literally, this is not true. There is one simple way that can protect you from ever being scammed in this way. Never use any link provided in any email with regards to any legitimate account you have. It is totally against all business practice to rely on this. All you need to do if you ever receive a concerning email is: 1 - Do not click any link provided. 2 - Go ahead and log in to the relevant account. If there are no flags, report the email as spam and delete it and forget about it. You can even talk to support to confirm, although not necessary.    TLDR: Never click ANY link in your email. I can't stress enough, just never click on any link in an email unless you have specifically requested it (password reset etc).

1) 2FA would only have worked if you gave the scammer your password. It would have done nothing to prevent what you were tricked into doing. 2) Google and YouTube would not send you a Google chat invite. Any official correspondence would be sent directly to your email. The reason why the email with the Google chat link shows up as a Google address is because it really was an automated email from Google. Whenever someone wants to chat with you in G-Chat, you'll get an email directly from Google notifying you that you have a new chat. The chat itself was not legit. This right here should have been your first red flag. 3) He had a Google logo for the YouTube Support account in Google Chat. Google and YouTube have been separate companies for a couple of years now ever since they split up their divisions and created Alphabet. Alphabet owns both of them. The fact that the Google Chat profile picture for YouTube Support was a Google logo instead of a YouTube logo would have been your second red flag.
Jokes on the scammers, you got your account back, idiots ü§£

Saddly bad english and outsourced vendors for tech support are no longer a suriprise and a red flag convincing this is might be a scam. Lots of companies are shifting now their support to teams based on the east Asia where this is how the "professional" support looks like or if internally even worse. It is not always the case, but very often it's just a waste of time to receive a support from legitimate vendor for the service we're paying for. Very often these vendors still use their own domains but have access to corporate domains.

Very cynical. Shows how you are very much trapped in old-paradigm, acting like some corporate entity vulnerable due to the usual systemic traits - scared about loss of profits and too busy. You didn't even mention the alert signal of repeated pressuring about permanent channel deletion as if it was an external entity with a clock ticking that support has to work against. And you didn't ask why exactly that second AdSense account would have come into existence. Plus, why would they require you to jump through those hoops? They should be able to do things more elegantly from their end. It was such classic leading of the victim, have you do what they cannot. The whole technical process was highly suspect. Including that the system told you exactly what would happen and you didn't hesitate to "replace"-"delete" your channel with an empty one. The only tolerance I can have here is the fact that GooTube runs their business like crap, so messy conduct is to be expected, I guess, but of couse it also conveys your decision to do business with them, and also, with them being potentially messy, you should also have considered that their incompetence might lead to you deleting your channel.  8:12 They should have made that domain name "support-younub". üòÜüòú  And then you gave him 'customer feedback'. ü§¶ The damage that can be causing is much greater than the benefit you're likely to gain. When I was an Uber driver I almost fell for a scammer who was using the Uber app to spoof me. He had me hook, line, ...........and then he asked me for my bank password to "Send me a bonus" because I was "such a good driver". Nope. I asked him why Uber needed a PW to send me money, seeing that they already did so every single night that I worked, as that is how they paid me. He had no answer. Later, after doing some research I found that many other drivers had fallen for this scam. Almost got me too, but I caught it at the last moment, thank the gods and goddesses.

I believed what they said, but I thought that it didn't matter since steam was a big company and obviously would have safeguards. I explained it to them and they kept pushing, only then did i realize it was a scam as they got more desperate.

As a Support Agent worker (not from Google/YouTube, and I won't say exactly what do I work for) I imagine most support agent projects work similarly. This message you received saying that your account was not compromised and they couldn't recover a deleted account is probably just an agent sending you a macro after reading just a bit of your case instead of going through all of it properly and calling it a day lol. While the things they said to you were *technically* true in a vacuum, it doesn't apply to your case specifically, it's probably just a standard reply they send to similar cases that they have to deal with all day.

Im currently in the process of getting settled into a new apartment, and so i went to submit a change of address to the United States Postal Service. I was recently scammed as well, and by the type of person I'm usually wary of, but I was in a bit of a personal crisis at the time so I let my guard down wanting to think that they were helping.  They just happened to show up in the right place at the right time.  It took some time to figure out that the crucial info I needed to recognize the scam was carefully hidden from view, and I wasn't the only one who didn't find it at first.  Luckily I was able to recognize it was a scam before I got too far into it, and I didn't lose more than $60, but yeah, it can happen to any of us.  The coincidence of timing paired with distraction works in their favor, and sometimes they're just better than most at hiding the most obvious red flags.  I'm a bit miffed at them, but I just took it in as a valuable learning experience and am moving on.  It's not something I'll forget anytime soon, tho, so I'm glad to add it to my mental library of "shitty things people do."  I'm sure it will come in handy some day.

Assuming this video isn't fake stuff for content, I lost all respect for you. Can't believe you were dumb enough to fall for this. I wouldn't have fallen for this when I was 5. Also, two more things. First, your channel URL is not gone. YouTube channel links are case sensitive. It took me two seconds to figure this out by going to your YouTube about page. Instead of typing ‚Äújimbrowning‚Äù in the URL, type ‚ÄúJimBrowning‚Äù with the capital letters for your names. Secondly, to answer your question about 2FA. If anyone is dumb enough to type their password in a form, he can easily trick them by saying "so just to verify that this is really you, I have prompted up a 2FA button on your phone. Can you press 'x' to verify it's you". This is truly sad. Did you get a head injury recently or have you always been this dumb?

Someone else may have already pointed this out, but the email you received IS actually from Google. It is not an email from the scammer; it is a notification, from Google, that you have received a Google Chat message (but have not yet marked as read). Yes this is a prime example of anyone being able to be scammed... it is all a matter of circumstance and if you toss a lot of lines when you are phishing you will surely hook one.  When you are primed with a circumstance/coincidence it makes the scam slightly more believable the chances of the scam working go up.   I hate those who claim only stupid people get scammed...  While I agree people need to be more vigilant... it is just not normal to be a sh** human being. Often times we assume other people are decent until we have reason to believe otherwise.   As my mother used to say something like being proud/acting like you know it all will surely set you up for the right type of scam... as in, you might know all kinds of scams and what to look for but being so confident can backfire in the right situation because you will think your judgement is infallible and won't second guess your decisions while being scammed.

Good to see your back. 2 step authentication is called Multi Factor Authentication or MFA in the IT field. You log into your account and get an SMS message to the device you setup previously or your email account.  Most companies go further and use OKTA Verify for MFA which uses facial recognition on IPHONES or Samsung phones.

Do you think you were targeted specifically because of what your channel and its contents are all about? Cuz honestly, the thought did cross my mind...
As someone who has to assist companies in basic phishing scams on a daily basis, it's not surprising that someone like Jim Browning can be hooked like this at all. Part of what makes these so scary is that at the moment of reading the initial email, it triggers a fear response that makes people forget common sense in the heat of the moment. Some tips, for both personal and at work: 1) Never trust your initial gut reaction. Your brain is wired to react to perceived threats, and a loss of income is up there in severity of reaction triggers 2) close the email, walk away and have a coffee. The time away will help you overcome the initial reaction 3) read the email again, and check who is sending. Jim covered the basics of this with the hover over an element 4) if unsure, ask a friend/colleague/IT to check the email for you. Having a second set of eyes, especially from someone who is aware of common phishing techniques will save you a LOT of hassle

I got scammed at work once. Was a busy night, got a call from someone claiming to be from HQ. They told me that in preparation for the new tablets we were receiving, which was a true situation that we were getting ready for, they needed to prep the digital Gift Cards. They needed me to grab a bunch, read off the numbers to them, then do a mock scan on a register to transfer them to the tablet to ensure e-cards were active and working. I knew that's not how that works. I knew we already sold e-cards on our website and the tablets were for internal use. I still went lizard brained and gave half the numbers before one of my coworkers stopped me and snapped me back to reality. God I felt so stupid, but all it takes is dropping your guard once to be had.
Kudos to you for having the humility to showcase your mistake like this. Even as you were going over the beginning of the story I had alarms going off about the matter, which just goes to show that ANY of us can simply be caught on a bad day if the circumstances are just right.  I have a bad habit of judging victims for stupidity, and this right here really helps adjust that unfair viewpoint. Glad you got the channel fixed in the end, and keep up the good work!

A
The Right Circumstances: Years ago I sent a donation to a good youth charity.  A day later I get a call from the bank asking if I would allow a charge by CC Bill of THE EXACT SAME AMOUNT, which was by sheer chance.  I almost fell for it, but thought why would the charge be going to CC Bill, when the charity has a business name, even though the charity owner's name was by sheer chance you guessed it, Bill.  I declined the charge, and the girl at the bank was clueless as to who CC Bill was, and was only making the call as they were instructed to verify charges made by CC Bill.  Turns out CC Bill was a company that billed for people like internet porn scumbags and illegally allowed scammers/thieves to charge to cards without having a CCV.  The CC Bill charging scammers wouldn't always go for the gusto, as they figure lesser amounts aren't always caught or noticed, and declined by banks with filters.  I then realized that the mom and pop hobby shop I had placed an order with recently had to be responsible.  When it came out, the owner was trying to get out of it and only said they may have been hacked.  They were hacked.  They were known good people in the hobby community, but were illegally storing card numbers on an internet connected computer, presumably due to laziness.  What happened is that either they were hacked, or their web developer created a backdoor and sold it.  I'll go 50/50 on that.  A few people lost entire accounts due to this hobby business.  That was the last time anyone other than Paypal, Ebay, or Amazon got my card numbers, as they have some real vested interest to not have these things happen.  Sad to say but that is an understandable reason for the large distributors/drop shippers like Amazon running smaller internet businesses out of business.

Whats the funniest thing in email scams, sometimes what looks like an obvious phishing might be just a mistaken recipient. Like i got obviously scammy email about paying DHL invoice. But when i got a second email on this i realized it is actually from RELEVANT address and someone was just looking through their address book in sloppy way and mistaken me for lady with same surname.
I almost fell for a scam email. It was from PayPal and said that $800 was charged go my account. I knew it was a mistake but never thought this was a scam. I called the number, which was only 1 digit away from the real thing, and the guy who answered was from India. That's when I knew right away.
This is a perfect example of complacency. Where it all seems fine until finally, something is just too off.

It's okay, I thought I was above falling for something like this, too. But several years ago, I got an "Apple ID" email about my account being hacked (Apple's emails I think will only say Apple but do not quote me). I'm not very familiar with Apple, having planted myself on Team PC/Android, but...I did use iTunes back then. I too wasn't paying a lot of attention.   At the time I got the email, my brother had just been in a bad wreck with my car (someone tried to either illegally pass another car on a curve or they were racing. Either way, they hit him head on). I had been jobless when this happened and the day after, finally got a job offer. We temporarily moved in with our mom as her apartment was easier for him to move around in with a fractured leg and other broken and fractured bones. Also, I at least got a silver lining with her house being much closer to my new job, so she didn't have far to take me.   But all of this is to say that I wasn't paying attention and filled out a form that even asked for my SSN, thinking that was some new security feature. I had already sent it before I took a closer look. Slightly broken English, capitalized letters where there shouldn't be, and a link that absolutely wasn't from Apple...I'd been duped, and in the most obvious way. Very embarrassing. I gave the info of the email to Apple and began keeping a close eye on my credit and personal info.   I've so far been lucky and I haven't had any fraud activity. Once I get to a confortable place where I'm personally not needing to use my credit for anything (I'm in the midst of moving right now and doing credit repair), I'll probably put a lock on it so it'll flag whenever my SSN is used for something.   But that's all it takes, being a little distracted and boom, the very obvious scam becomes less obvious. So, I try not to judge too hard when others fall for these things.

I think I dodged a tech support scam from avg. I contacted them on their page because avg kept blocking one of the sites I upload files to for work. I wanted to know how to whitelist the site.  The guy kept trying to get me to install a remote desktop so he could fix it. I was leery of this and just asked him to instruct me. He spun a line about how thar would be a temporary fix, but if he does it it's permanent. And i said that's fine, I want to do it myself.  While he was waffling I decided to just google my answer and solved it on my own.  Also he kept asking me for specific log files. I couldn't understand why he wanted log files when all I wanted to do was whitelist the site.   Biggest telltale sign that it was a scammer was that after the fact I never got an email asking me to rate my support. Every time I have ever interacted with support anywhere for the last decade I get one of those forms. I think I dodged a bullet.

I hadn't watched this video thinking this was about a small account setting mistake or some copyright trouble or something, but watching the video it's terrifying how intelligent scammers are getting, to the point they got a guy who professionally busts scammers to actually follow some instructions. This is actually why I don't really like people boasting about how they wasted a scammer's time, reverse-scammed a scammer, etc. They might be entertaining but all they're achieving is helping scammers close up holes in their methods at the expense of some time wasted. In the case of Jim's videos they're very informative about how scammers operate, what kind of vulnerabilities they go after, etc so there's much value to be had, but just sharing stories for the lolz isn't doing anyone a favor but the scammers.  Anyway, I'm glad Jim got his channel back. I hope people don't take the wrong message from what happened to this channel.

i like when the scammer get scam 14:35. oooh the irony.
Yep, even the brightest can be fooled. I'm a computer engineer, I've always advised clients, no matter how legitimate an email from any  business or site from your phone company, ISP, paypal, Google or bank saying you have a problem looks legitimate, or if there is a case number, never reply directly to the email, or click on any links. Close the email and immediately contact the company in question through numbers you know are genuine from when you signed up, and start a new ticket looking into it from the parent site you signed up on. Anything that says urgent you are being canceled by whoever I don't even open, I just delete them without reading, and contact the company directly. These days I also advise clients friends and family unless you are expecting a prearranged link from a company, friend or family don't open the email. Not when you can hop over and start a chat in FB, or shoot off a quick text, or Godforbid call someone directly to verify it first.

The hunter becomes the hunted
It took years, but Jim Browning finally had his properly named account. Moving to Syria amid national conflict. Relocating to Turkey when the situation in Syria collapsed. The strain on his family. All the hours spent learning the ways of the tech support scammer. Jim Browning would finally have his vengeance. It started back when members of his family mentioned he could save and upload videos of his family on the internet. All he had to do to share videos of his grandchildren with the world was to create a youtube account. His interest piqued, he started up his PC. Jim then located the internet browser and searched youtube. Here with guidance from his children he went to create account. When asked for his account name he simply wished to be known by his god-given name. He pecked the letters on his keyboard. Little did he know, some other person had already taken his account name for themselves. Stunned he checked the post-it note covered walls of his computer desk. There was user account information for all the websites he used except youtube. "This must be a mistake," he gasped. This other Jim Browning was having quite a successful time curating his channel. Jim took a deep breath and held it before sighing heavily. "Usurper," he muttered as he carefully laid out his plans to take back what was his. Jim took an interest in this pretender's account content. After speaking with his wife and getting his coffee, Jim perused the videos of this false Jim's channel. Tech support scams were not foreign to him. He had answered many phone calls ended abruptly in disappointment and frustration. Expecting calls from the grandkids only to be greeted by Christopher from Microsoft or an odd sounding woman telling him that his car warranty had expired. Jim set out to take down the man using HIS name. No longer would the world be subjected to the intricacies of phone call and email scams. The world will see the light, shone upon them by his darling grandchildren. Jim sipped his morning coffee and focused on the laptop his son helped set up for him. It was time to get to work.

I used to work for a big company that started with the letter A and shares a name with a famous rainforest, and listening to all the people that fell for scams has convinced me to always just call the company they're claiming to be from's official support number or email to ask about it. I had to listen to far too many people in tears over being tricked out of their money and not being able to do anything about it. I'm glad YouTube was able to help you out.

Damn, this EXACT same thing happened to PsychedSubstance
That must be the lamest attempt at phishing I've seen someone intelligent fall for. there are several small errors that paint this email as fake. There isn't a comma after the opening hi, and businesses like google don't use direct language they are as vague as possible so accusing him of having a duplicate account isn't their style. Next they used an uppercase W on the word we, they wont use the word permanently they will use the word indefinitely as its more vague and can be appealed. A lack of other various punctuations and most of all a very unprofessional tone makes this seem suspicious and desperate.
Damn dude.. sorry that shit happened. Thanks for being open enough to share..
We all have our blind spots, don't feel bad about it. I think the moment they told you to delete your channel would have been a good time to call YouTube and ask some questions. I've had a close call with a scammer pretending to be from a government organisation here in Australia that was targeting my mum. She had an online store a few years ago, and they were claiming that something she was selling had been recalled and was dangerous.  While it is true that this product had been recalled (we checked into it, and that part was true), my mum had never sold any of them at the time she had them, and that was about a year before it was recalled. They were demanding all the information of everyone we sold them to, and were very aggressive in threatening legal action and so on. My mum was worried about the initial email we received which is why she called me about it.  In the heat of the moment, they have you on edge and worried, you stop thinking clearly and go into tunnel vision. Thankfully, I asked them for more information and things weren't adding up, so we were able to catch it before trying to comply with them. Not that we had any information to send them at that point, but it was likely only a matter of time before they asked for some information they could use.  I'm glad you got it all fixed. Again, don't feel too bad about it. As you said, they got you at the right time, and it really did seem quite legit. Thankfully, you got it all fixed, and we can all learn something from this. ^_^

The fact that these huge corporations are completely opaque and unreachable is what helps the scammers the most. If there was a way to communicate effectively with Google, instead of all theses hoops they make us jump through and all the obfuscation they employ in order to avoid dealing with the public, it would be much harder to scam people. And the same goes for banks, Paypal, service providers etc. That's why the scammer disguise themselves as those entities.
I was scammed similarly on steam. A friends account was hacked and the scammer was obviously  reading off a script but at the time I did no t realize .He sent me a link on steam which I clicked expecting some  kind of free skin. After this he told me to mess with some of my inventory setting and to send my skins over to a friend in the mean time.. By removing the pricy setting on my account the scammer could see who I was trading with. He quickly changed his avatar and profile pick to my friends, The problem is the scammer had a level 0 steam account  so when I confronted him he hacked my steam account. Lockley steam support helped me recover my account.
