damn they got psychedsubstance with this too and also tried to get someordinarygamers
I almost got scammed out of my steam account. This person had taken over the account of one of my steam friends, and then used his account to tell me over steam chat that he "accidentally reported me to steam for fraud". I was then directed to friend request someone claiming to be a steam moderator. They asked me to join them on discord in DMs. Strike 1. They got me to take some screenshots of my purchase history (nothing usable, they probably just wanted to see if I had games in my account), and then instructed me to log out of steam on all devices, and tell him when I've done so. At this point I was uncomfortable, and had already expressed irritation that I was being treated as guilty until proven innocent (why wasn't I notified by steam directly? Why am I having to reach out, rather than steam?). Strike 2. So in an instance of rebellion, I logged out, logged right back in, and told him after the fact that I _would_ log out, and then back in, but I wouldn't tell him when until after, then waited a minute and told him it was done. He then gave me the spiel about how I somehow have to be logged out in order to have the ban lifted. Strike 3.   I then called him out on the things I'd already complained about, about how it made no sense that I would have to be logged out to have a ban lifted when no other system in the universe has that requirement (I could believe that a quick login token reset is necessary, but not being logged out during the whole process), and asked for proof that he was who he said he was, having already reached out to the friend on discord and steam support with a general request asking about this so-called moderator. After he sent me a "certificate" saying he's "reddit officer licensed" (STRIKE 4), I shared the screenshot of me contacting the real steam support and said "I don't believe you.". To which he blocked me. Sure enough, the friend later replied confirming they got hacked and steam replied saying that person doesn't work for them, and that they would look into the compromised friend. He got his account back after 1-2 days and the scammer was eventually banned from steam wholesale.  After this incident, I privated my steam account, because I'm pretty sure I became a target because the guy saw my account worth on steamdb.  Just goes to show that even the most cynical and savvy of us can be social-engineered. The red flag for me was when I was told to log out of steam "on all devices, including your mobile authenticator"

And given some scam victims you've contacted have said things like "I've already been on the phone with this guy for hours," it seems like sunk cost fallacy provides a big boost to the scammer's success rate from there.  At that point someone who's worried about their account is probably more likely to fill out the form to "complete the process."

Looking at the start of this video and this attacker didn't send you an e-mail: They sent you a chat message via Google Chat and because you weren't online in GChat, Google Chat generated the e-mail you received to notify you about the missed chat message. (Note the "via Google Chat", "Open in Google Chat", etc.) Of course that should be an immediate red flag as support is unlikely to use chat to contact you.  The only interesting part there is that they somehow managed to trick Google Chat into showing them as "YouTube Support". (Guessing they just used that as first/lastname combination?)

I managed to figure it all out but it was so confusing.  In particular it's really unclear which channel you're deleting when you select the "replace" option.  Even after successfully pulling it off I still hardly understand how brand accounts work.  Not gonna lie it was pretty clever of the scammer to take advantage of the confusing process.

Which is why he had two different phones and he already had his IP reversed himself.  So he knew he could give you a plausible explanation to where he is from. Remember that scammers are always one step ahead and you need to be extra careful. Being a developer myself, I have seen fair share of scammers try to scam me too. I always keep an eye open for these things. Even reported on case to Cyber Crime in Hyderabad, India. It is so easy to get fooled. Doesn't matter who you are. Like you said, the circumstances just need to be right.
I am glad to you are okay. Is it possible for you to alert the Turkish authorities about this uncaring hacker?

The scammers are getting smarter, to the point that they tried to get money out of Jim and almost got his channel deleted. Even Jim almost fell for a scam. Be very careful out there!
I was going through web scamming with my parents and wanted examples of how convincing some of these guys could be. I was really confused that I couldn't get any hits of Jim's directly published content, and immediately smelt a rat. A quick google search later and the truth was revealed. The guy I was planning on using to illustrate how some scammers work was actually going to do just that, but not in the manner and timeframe I originally planned for !  Fair play to him for publishing this video and coming clean about what happened. As was stated both at the beginning and end of the vid *anyone* can fall victim to this sort of scam if the stars are aligned correctly. All it takes is a bit of inattention at the end of a long day, or an incoming email lining up with a real life event such as a bank account change or placing an order of some kind and you too could join the list of victims.  If you try to convince yourself it will never happen to you you're pretty much guaranteeing it will ! Again, kudos to Jim for putting his hands up to what happened; hopefully we will all learn something from this !
Don't feel too bad about it Jim, thankfully it's been a decade since "they" last got me but my circumstances were similar: Buttload of work, multitasking 5 things, tired, text "legit" enough to pass at first glance... whoever says they're invulnerable is lying to themselves.

@1:14 I don't use Google Chat but I don't think it's as sophisticated as you make it seem. He didn't send any email. That email you received just looks like an automated email from Google letting you know that you got a missed message in Google Chat (Microsoft does the same thing with MS Teams).  If you read the footer of the email you see that it states that you got a message in the chat from a "Google User".  The email itself is perfectly legit. - All the scammer did was send you a chat message.   The message they sent was hard to read and full of grammatical errors, but that's easily overlooked when it comes to instant messages (almost expected). That's what played in their favour.

8/1/2021 - My old subscription link is working normally.  Keep up the fight.  Remember, the superhero is always nearly taken out by the bad guys in the middle of the movie.  The superhero always comes back stronger than before and takes the bad guys down!  I am an IT guy, I see these types of attacks every day.  This one was pretty convincing. Unless you are sure the email is legitimate, never click on a link. Complicated software (which this whole move/replace channel business is) used to come with documentation and full explanations of how the software worked and what the software would do.  These days, in the age of the tiny 5-inch screen, that documentation has been replaced by a couple of vague, inaccurate, incomplete lines of text written in about 90 seconds by a company intern.
Different world, that.    Political commentators on the right are very well aware of these processes.   But you'd have to be following those political commentators and the various channels that cover politics to know this one was a scam from the very start.

Always be suspicious of links/claims in emails no matter how legit they seem. Always go to the source first to verify. And while you are there, check the *_SSL/TLS/HTTPS certificate thumbprint_* to make sure you aren't a victim of a MITM attack. It isn't a 100% guarantee, as many legit websites do have multiple SSL cert thumbprints, but most websites only have one. Always best to check just in case. Because if the thumbprint matches, then it is probably guaranteed safe.    Do a search to find a site (or two or three) you trust to provide this information. Suggested: "Web server certificate fingerprints".
You‚Äôre custom link is back now.
Getting scammed can be extremely painful emotionally. i coach my elderly relatives regularly on how to avoid getting scammed, mainly just telling them over and over to never give any passwords, never give any money, never buy any giftcards, but it still happens. all of my grandparent's have been succesfully scammed at least once, and they were massively embarrassed by it. two of them never told me they were scammed at all, and i only found out after they had passed (from old age). luckily the amount they lost was affordable, so it was more like having a nice watch stolen. it could have been MUCH worse.  No one really is immune to getting scammed, even security researchers. All it takes is for things to line up just right, and a scammer who is just that good to get a bit lucky and then not make a mistake. I guess my point is, if you were scammed, don't beat yourself up over it. consider it like getting your pocket picked in new york in a busy crowd. and its ok to feel hurt by it, it can feel really violating. There is a general trust you automatically give every stranger you meet. A trust that they won't randomly attack you, and that they aren't malicious. This trust is human nature, and getting scammed is a real violation of it. Everybody, go remind your grandparents to never click any links in emails, and never give anyone any money for any reason, even if its Jesus Christ calling and asking for 5 bucks!

The best way to avoid any email scams is to always call the company the message supposedly came from or to email their support to ensure nothing is actually going on with your account. I've been doing this for months and it's saved me quite a few times from convincing phishing emails.

M. Browning exhibits an important safety tip.  The requests at 8:42 to "Please send us your phone number" and "How can I talk to you?" at 11:40, if answered, would have provided the scammer with a way around Two-Factor Authentication (for certain forms of 'phone-based 2FA in certain countries).  It involves scamming The 'Phone Company as well, but as we can see, this is a person who knows how to scam.  M. Browning correctly refused to divulge xyr 'phone number, and the lesson is that even if one thinks that one is back in charge again one should not become complacent.  The advice to not give your personal information still holds, even when you are trying to confront a scammer afterwards. The scammers are *still* trying their tricks, even when you think that you have the upper hand.
RETURN OF THE KING
This is why I always, ALWAYS try and find a contact number to call somewhere if I think that they sent an email.  Now while I don't think YouTube has a phone number you can call, they do have live support through their domain.  Just click the menu icon, and go to the bottom where it says "contact us" before you go messing with your account to verify it. :)

I want to put a quick note about two step authentication. If you use the same password for your email and other things then two factor authentication will not be able to help you unless its the one where you tap a button on your phone. Please do not use the same password on your email that you use for anything else.

To be fair, it's not that it's easy to be scammed, it's that technology has become so convoluted that the error appeared genuine to being with. We shouldn't ever be in a position were an account inside of another account can accidentally duplicated itself, and then becoming a problem. Red flags should have immediately went off regardless to your new phone, but since most apps have away of taking over for us and doing things we never ask because companies like Google want their fingers in all of our pies 24/7 it was actually plausible for a moment. That moment of weakness wasn't from a good scam, it was from bad tech.  Companies like Google have to be better companies. It was never acceptable. We don't need compa nies that twist our data to the point where simple things become complicated just so can they can muscle their way into our lives without our permission.

Damn, the youtube support is so ineffective. When I was a kid, I created seperate email address for my youtube channel, and later I realised I could just move them to my main email ID using the make it a brand account technique. Its a fairly straightforward process and it's just that you only completed half of it before you thankfully realising it was a scam. Technically you didn't lose your channel nor was it "deleted" at any point and youtube didn't do any "magic" to bring your channel back like some other comments are suggesting. I can't believe they took days to just send over the rest of the steps to fully move your channel, it takes one "how to move YouTube channel to a different email" in google search. Anyways glad that you got sorted it out finally and damn if Jim can be convinced by a scam then I indeed am really scared.

Just goes to show how vulnerable we can be if a scam targets a demographic we're a part in.  I fell for a scam when I was about 14. I spent a lot of time on the computer and might have ignorantly installed a trojan -I don't recall what specifically might have triggered it but my best guess is I may have clicked one of those pop up ads about "playing Minecraft for free" that show up on youtube videos sometimes. I got the popup on my computer that said I had a fatal error and had to contact microsoft support. It had the logos, fonts and everything. I was so worried about my parents finding out that I agreed to paying a ridiculous 300 something dollars for a "3 year protection plan". I absolutely should have known better, with the thick accents, busy background noise, and with how rude and impatient they got with me. They at one point had remote access to my computer and had me give them my card info via the notepad app. It still makes me sick to think about, because it wasn't until my dad walked in on me, realized what was happening, and shut off my computer and wifi that I had realized what had happened.  Thankfully the bank could recover the money I had lost. I still feel stupid about it sometimes, but I was a kid who thought she knew everything about how the internet works. Every few months or so I still get scam calls, and every single time it makes me realize how disgusting and sad these people are. I've had a pretty major fascination with the ever-evolving scams since then and continue to really appreciate the knowledge you and KitBoga spread. It seems like every day there are new disguises for shady emails, calls, and text messages. Now in my early twenties, living with my grandparents who are brand new to the world of iphones, computers, and prime overnight shipping, I've really felt pressed to ensure they know what these people want and how they can get it from them. My grandma has already told off a few scam phone calls which just feels great. Again, I can't stress enough how grateful I am that channels like these exist. Not only do they inform and educate people and their families, but they remind people like me to be attentive and cautious. Bless you. I'm glad your channel was recovered.  Edit: Also sick that he tried to pull your heartstrings for a last minute buck. "I want to get out" bs. Absolutely shameless.

they got you to make a blank channel and then they told you to do all of this being signed into the blank channel which can be seen top right of YouTube visible in these other signs of trickery: 1. 6:33 it says replace on your main channel, therefore meaning you would replace your main channel with the blank channel you were signed into at the time. this is just understanding the English and the accounts. you are signed into the blank channel(visible top right) and it says replace for the main channel - replacing the main with the blank. 2. 5:29 it says delete channel for the main channel which seems a bit sketchy as it says delete channel LOL. 3. 6:26 it says move channel and being signed into the blank channel you would be moving the blank channel into its place of the main channel ultimately replacing the main with the blank. 4. 5:06 if you look close to the middle it says: "YouTube channel being moved. This is the channel that will be moved". You don't want to move a blank channel over in place of the main channel. However busy you are you wouldn't rush over your livelihood. Scammers try to scam me almost every single day, if not, every two to three days. I have a couple businesses, so I am a bigger target than the average joe. This has been happening for years (at least 6 years) and I have never been scammed. If I wasn't so busy with my businesses, I would definitely be a scambaiter since I get so many calls/emails from scammers so often.   Jim, I know how good you are, but I spotted the poor grammar and spelling right away when you didn't. The poor structure/formatting and the random capitalization gave it away. The real Google support doesn't make those rookie mistakes. You are still a thousand times better than me at baiting and busting scammers, so I will chalk this up to you being tired or distracted as the reason for overlooking the signs.  On a side note, I would like to learn from you so that I can be somewhat helpful in busting scambaiters. Since I get calls from scammers so often, I figure I might as well take advantage of those opportunities rather than simply pissing them off on the phone (which I love doing btw). I am really good at keeping them on the phone for a long, long time; however, I want to do more than just waste their time and piss them off. I want to actually help in getting them busted and shut down. I have a few ideas that can accelerate that process as well. If you teach me everything you know, I will not only make time to apply those skills, but I will share my ideas with you and the scambaiter community. Let me know if you are interested.

This may be controversial, but I think Google is almost entirely responsible for this. They are allowing themselves to be easily impersonated, their instructions were unclear, their spam filter didn‚Äôt catch an email like this (tho it looks like that may not be applicable because you‚Äôre not on gmail), they likely don‚Äôt make it clear what email addresses they actually use for support, and it looks like they took far too long to reinstate your channel.   Obviously the people running these scams are actually culpable. But it‚Äôs totally unacceptable in my opinion that a 1.8 trillion dollar company has all these holes in security. More generally, large companies should not be able to push security responsibility onto individual users. That‚Äôs like Coca-Cola blaming people‚Äôs lack of exercise for obesity when their drinks have 60g of sugar. We‚Äôre the hecking customers, Google is supposed to work for us. I would defer to others on the topic of authentication keys and biometrics, but tldr the era of passwords should be over. Whether or not I get scammed should not be a factor of how smart (or attentive or tech savvy) I am; human error shouldn‚Äôt even be a factor when Google employs the smartest people in the world and the best AI we‚Äôve ever seen. This feels ranty, but it just doesn‚Äôt make sense that the human error of regular people is the deciding factor when we‚Äôre supposed to have trillion dollar companies on our side.

I'm starting to feel like those emails are from line alias spam mail and not from me being hacked and sending myself those kinds of mail. Despite what the real official YouTube (or apple or facebook or any other social media giant) says, *NOTHING* gets really deleted from their servers; they can *ALWAYS* (if they want as in a FBI search warrant) get the contents back because "deleting" means always "remove from user reach"; nice to see they moved the 'deleted' contents back to reach

Google needs to take responsibility for this scam, as it all happens in their control... Google Chat, Youtube and Google Forms.  I was shocked that Jim could have fallen victim to such a scam... but it was sent from Google! As soon as it was clear it wasn't spoofed (i.e. from Google IP) the scammer has full attention and trust of the victim.   Why does Google allow someone to use google.com domain?  Why can someone register with "youtube" as a chat alias? Simple word filter!  Why can people create forms asking for peoples passwords? It is always going to be a scam.   I hope Google/Youtube takes action on the above points. Not everyone may have 2SA enabled and it may still leave you locked out even if the scammer cannot get in. I was really confused about the transfer meaning channel deletion, that seemed a bit strange also. I am glad Jim is back... I was away from Youtube for a week, and saw this video worried that the content was gone.
My job involves picking up the pieces after something like this happens and while I can asssure you that many companies hate this kind of stuff and (My employer, at least) has taken every step possible to make these kinds of scams as hard as possible to actually pull off and are still looking for ways to improve...it really all comes down to the end user.   No matter what we do, no matter how many restrictions we put in place and the number of people we hire to help us reverse engineer these scams to plug the holes we cannot stop you from giving your login information to another person, so keep that in mind.

"No legitimate team asks for passwords"   Support techs from Evolve IP out of PA ask for passwords all the time. Even after I asked them to add a note not to do that, they would do that whenever they needed access to our accounts on their systems, generally for testing.  So it's not *quite* a hard-and-fast rule that real teams don't ask for passwords. *Competent* teams do not ask for passwords

Spiffing brit fell for this scam
well i  am glad u have your yt channel back idk how i would have felt if i lost something like that
In that email I see a request for you to click on something, that should have been your first clue it was a scam. I learned a long time ago that emails prompting you to click on a link is how scammers do it. NEVER CLICK ON A LINK EVEN IF YOU THINK IT IS LEGIT. If you needed to contact google you contact them DIRECTLY independent of the email. I cannot be scammed and that is not because I am some special genius. I understand two things common to all scams. First they do not do things normally. Second they prompt you to send money. Those two things are always present in scams. My brother recorded a conversation he recently had with a real estate scammer saying they were interested in buying the property. So he asked what they are offering for it. They did not give a number. That was right off the top a big clue. Then they start asking for details about the property like how many bathrooms and I was thinking this is obviously a scam because if someone were really interested in buying the property they would already know all that. Then when he asked again what they are offering they still gave no number. So clearly there was nothing legitimate about this. Then there is the posting of free stuff on Craigslist. There was a post of something for free, the he contacted them asking the address so he can come and get it, then they ask for a photo of his ID. There is NO REASON for someone giving away something for free to ask for a photo of your ID. I think this was an identity theft scam. Scams are obvious because they do not do things normally.  If anything looks like it is not normal in any way it is a scam.

Grabify seems like a good back up for when someone from your past tries to be an online "bully". Being able to threaten to forward their IP details to the local authorities will get them to instantly scatter.
Warning: Don't expect a scammer to not break through a 2FA, some are very manipulative and can potentially get the 2FA code from you anyway if you let them (they hide the meaning or try and convince you it's something else or that they sent it and want to verify you, all the while building pressure). If you end up using 2FA (recommended for anything of value to you), then maintain the rule to NEVER give anyone else the 2FA code! A real tech support does not need or ask for that code, only scammers ask for it.

I wonder if the guy wanted to know your old (not current) password to reset the 2FA.  There is also sms 2FA fallback which is often susceptible to sim hijacking.
Something that might also be worth noting is that this email has horrible grammar, really basic mistakes that will make it look unprofessional as fuck, hence giving away that it's probably not official. A lot of scammers are not aware of the fact that professionalism does not exclusively equal to fancy words, but also good grammar.

Yeah I assume all emails can be phishing emails regardless of what the return email address says, since... I want to say even those can be presented inaccurately, and the real email address will be hidden in the header. Good companies tell you specifically in their emails "do not click any links in this email, go log into the proper website url yourself" to confirm things, whereas technically-legit companies that aren't paying proper attention to netiquette will include links and tell you to click them (I've seen... paypal or amazon or something do this and they're legit emails), and sadly that encourages non-savvy customers to click links in phishing emails as well.
Horrible experience, but thanks for sharing! It's not easy to get duped and then share that experience with everyone but we all needed it.

it is easy to make an email legit.  1. break into the servers and steal the template files that are used by the system to generate the email.  2. set up an account and get an email then change the details .  for example if you want to get a roadrunner isp copyright violation email so you can start spamming roadrunner isp customers you would.  1. break into roadrunner's servers and steal the email templates used to automatically generate the emails.  2. get a roadrunner account and start downloading and seeding copyrighted stuff in hopes you will get an email.  then change the contents of the email and send them to other roadrunner customers  and so on  all 170+ videos are not lost. if you have them on your hard drive you can re upload them. yess!!! you will be spending gigs of bandwidth and waiting  a long time if you are on slow connection.  you may not get back all your comments, likes and subscribers.  while you can ask the viewers to re like and re subscribe you will not get the comments because some may not comment or even remember what they said.  a reset can make a phishing scam look more legit because the scammer can send the scam email right after the reset.  moral of the story never respond to emails even if they look legit and coincide in timing

This is why no matter how authentic an email, phone call, text or any thing else may seem, you NEVER just use the supplied way to respond. Always consider it a scam first and then work out if its real.  Every time ive gotten anything that seems legit, I CALL them on a number that i know it correct or for a youtube account you might have to create your own email to send to support or whatever. Always start your correspondence. Once you contacted them, inform them about whatever it was you received and if its legit they will have it in their system or be able to connect you to someone who would know. NEVER trust an email, phone call, text, or mail that you did not already know was coming and even then confirm it. If i know my sister is emailing me a link, i will call to make sure im looking at the right email.

Wow. Very convincing. Having worked for a very large tech company dealing with security issues like this, to a normal person it'd be very easy to do. Also you were distracted which didn't help. A couple things I noticed were the greeting in the email just said "Hi" and normally emails from companies have your name, a simple "Hi Jim" or something. If they are vague like "Hi customer" or "Hello YouTuber" or dont say any name, that's a red flag. Also, never click chat links in emails. They can easily be spoofed, even on official platforms. The best thing to do is if you're unsure whether or not the email is legitimate, contact YouTube/Google directly and ask them about the email and whether your account seriously has an issue. Sure its a few extra steps rather than conveniently clicking the link but that's the only way to be 100% sure you're speaking to the actual support team. The form was a dead giveaway though.

OK I only needed to see the first three minutes . Here are the Red Flags you ignored : 1.You Tube does not send notices in Chat if you get them delete Chat . Chat is accessible by anyone on the web so it is INSECURE to use for monetized Channels . You Tube uses its Creator Community Guidelines address for all notices and they do not use Google to send them  . THAT IS A RED FLAG ! 2." We Are Waiting For Your reply " You Tube never waits for replies ! You may appeal a decision AND THAT IS IT ! Waiting is a phishing Scam word urging you to open the email ... Any personal emails from YT are Community Guideline Violations found by the Algorithm and sent to a team to approve then you get a standard email telling you the punishment and you can appeal .Man you are monetized you should know this ! ANOTHER RED FLAG ! 3. ONLY USE the You Tube Creator Community emails OPEN NO OTHERS . That is their line of communication only . 4 Your largest Mistake was communicating with them ! Never communicate with Phishing Hackers ! BIG RED FLAG !  So You Tube did not delete your account the Hackers have taken it over and will now get the monetization cash . You need to notify YT that your channel has been hacked and PLEASE my friend ! Stop emailing the Hackers ! So if YT restores your channel under a different URL you can resume monetization but you will need a new bank account . And remember Jim we 3.33 million subs WANT YOU BACK !

Hey man, some people can be very convincing, especially former employees who know how the real thing looks. Mad props for how you handled this. It would have broken a lesser man I'm sure. It's a lot of work put into a channel so I get how you thought this was real. I mean anyone can be scammed. Former employees are the number one suspect to me. I used to work for a gas company and had a scammer reported to me on the job. I should correct that, I had to alert the customer that they were being targeted for a scam. The fake bill was so convincing it was made on our stationary with the watermark. Blank forms were stolen from the worker and they faked a bill in their home pc with a real bill as the template. Nothing matched, fake number, fake amount... but a real address to mail in the bill and a phone number to call which was not ours. The customer was lucky, had our number pre programed into their phone instead of calling the scammer to fork over their credit card. It took months to find the person and he did scam some people who just mailed in the fake amount to the scammers address, but all payments were stopped beforehand by the banks and by the mailing service. Always report what you can, even if it's only 100 bucks... don't just pay and say "all well I got scammed." Always report, you can help others.
O

*why you should use 2fa on Google* I have been scared of trying 2fa because it seemed like it would be annoying but honestly, after getting a spook by having someone log in from another country for months without my knowledge, i enabled 2fa for my Google account. Turns out that it really is not annoying. I get a notification on my phone when i login from a new device and just need to click "yes". Takes 2 seconds. Highly recommend everyone does the same.
Great content Jim. It's always good to let people know that even the most attentive and experienced of us are able to be scammed if circumstances align. I had similar when an ISP scammer called me right as my internet had gone down and I was about to pick up the phone to call the real support. Similarly to you, because I was distracted and it matched what was happening to me, I fell for it, right until they started asking for personal information, at which point I rumbled them. It was a big wake up call, and allowed me a lot of compassion towards those that are scammed by 'obvious con jobs'. In my work as IT support, I would often have to deal with the fallout of people being scammed and having their computers and accounts compromised, and after my experience I would always make sure to tell the victims not to feel stupid or foolish, because anyone can fall for these things. Cognitive dissonance that you are too smart to be scammed, and denial that you have been scammed, are weapons in the scammers arsenal, and allows for more scams down the line. Nobody should be embarrassed or ashamed that they have been scammed, and the more stories told, the more information is out there for people to avoid this in the future, for themselves and for others. You do great work, and I applaud you.

Yep. So many scammers and it's too easy to get scammed. I don't click on any links in Emails unless I am certain of what they do and where they go. Government emails are the easiest to follow as they tend to have a .gov I believe in the Email.  How you got scammed and what you say in the end is correct. Anyone can get scammed especially if the conditions are just right. I once got scammed, lost an account and I knew it was going to happen but I had a bit of peer pressure and guilt tripping going on. So I gave in to try and get a free game to play with them.  I have hundreds of scam emails, frightening ones as well when they try to make you out to be a criminal. You freak out and wonder about things until you realize all the details. Like if the scammer says they take photos of you and your camera is never plugged in or has a piece of cardboard attached to it. How your always consciously avoiding things knowing that your camera could be spied through. ESSPECIALLY if your computer is in the rooms. As much as we think we build up walls to be aware of scams, unfortunately were not always good enough to respond as we would expect ourselves too.  Don't click links, Don't read these emails. Don't be played. And importantly it's better not to respond. Some of these emails we get suggest your a criminal and that you did something illegal. I've been told that they are scammers and that they will genuinely put dirt on you to get you in trouble with the law, even if not by your own actions. They have some way of tunneling that kind of stuff to your system and making you actually guilty. Through different means. Via a malicious installer of software or by other means. Just responding I've been told is enough to confirm that your doing something wrong even if your not. I don't know how true this is, I've seen a few emails but deleted them. They area threatening with no real basis, making claims without evidence. Sometimes they actually somehow get your passwords and use that to scare you by telling you your password of which then starts creating a situation where your freaking out and panicking. Not because you did anything wrong but how did they get your password? Turns out my password was leaked at the time from a cyber attack on a gaming site that distributed keys was somewhere based in Dutch or Germany from memory. And they also never put out a PSA which one one realized and apparently they broke laws by keeping it under the table.  I can't find a record of who it was or where I found out information, but once your information goes on the dark net it becomes impossible to destroy. Apparently scammers go on forums to bag and share all the information they stole to be cool, and then everyone downloads and pumps that data into different scams.  Now if your a younger person maybe between the ages of 13 and 18, these kind of things will scare your really bad, especially if you think it's true. Scammers can also now pretty much fabricate a false "True story" that maybe able to put you somewhere you never where. At a point, they can say you did something that you 100% never did and be charged because they fabricated a recording. It's to do with that imitation video clip technology. Get enough pictures of someone and the computer can generate all the motions. A person can then sit in their chair, take the actions they said you did, but put your face on top of their own to make it look like you.  Very scary stuff. All someone needs to do to make you look like a scammer is put a file in your Windows folder, call it at Runtime and then trigger anything to happen. It happened to my friend and I helped him out of if when we were kids because I was tech savvy. Also me helping him led to our friendship.  Look after yourself guy's! And do the right thing!!!

But my god, the headlines of these articles where so snarky, it was if they where on the scammers side, what a pain)

Yawp, it can happen to anyone under the wrong conditions. This is why I worry about my mom, because whenever I bring up scammer tactics she always insists that she could never be fooled by scammers. And yet, she's been borderline scammed twice now. Once by an individual at a store who was signing up people to switch their cable provider to Dish, which caused her headaches for months because some of the services they sold her never worked or weren't even installed and they tried to insist on huge early cancellation fees despite never delivering working services, and once when she clicked on an Internet ad for cheaper car insurance, which caused her to have to ignore a constantly ringing phone for weeks as every insurance company from legit down to one-man operations called her and tried to pressure sell her new insurance. Insisting that you could NEVER fall for a scam is a matter of pride, not reality, and pride is doubly dangerous as you get older, so I thank you for pointing out that even the most experienced and savvy individuals can be fooled if you catch them at the wrong moment with the right tactic.

The base for this scam seems to be YouTube & Google's fault for not making it clear that messages coming through Google Chat are not actually from Google or YouTube. It's a real email from Google showing you a message not-from-Google but it's framed in a way that, given an official-looking user-defined name, looks like a real correspondence from Google.

About 10 min after I realized this it got flagged by Google due to be reported for phishing so at least that‚Äôs a good sign less people believed it.

It's pretty stupid of Google to allow its domain to be used in emails.  A more general rant is in email applications in general. 20 years ago it was normal to see the full email headers from whichever client you were using. Now, all that info is obscured and it's an absolute pain to find this info (especially on android mail client or even Windows Mail). Being able to see the sender's IP and email headers clearly would zap all these phishing emails dead but these software designers/vendors want to dumb down interfaces and make other idiotic design decisions to the detriment of security and common sense.

Whenever I get ANY email claiming an issue with an account I ALWAYS manually go to the account page on the website first. and check for notification/messages. if there's nothing there than I'm super sceptical.  But like Jim said. ANYONE can be scammed if the circumstances are right. That's why they send out massive bulk emails. Hundreds of thousands will be ignored/reported/deleted. But the few that bite is all it takes to make it worth it. But yeah ALWAYS navigate to account/support pages yourself. Every link has a risk attached.  Another note. I've actually seen some VERY convincing phishing attempts and simply going to the website manually and checking the accounts page there I've avoided (thus far) all phishing attempts on myself.

Hope you're doing better than ever right now Jim.
You seem to misunderstand how you received that email. The email you showed is nothing but a notification generated by Google Chat (the successor to Hangouts) to inform you that somebody sent you a message while you were offline. The person in question simply created a Google account and used the service to send a instant message to you, which google notified you of with this email. You should‚Äôve picked up on this by reading the first line of that email ‚Äúmessaged you on Google Chat‚Äù.
If a website sends you an email, they'll have that email sent to you through the inbox / messaging section on the website too. These days, I only pay attention to messages within the platform. Everything else I delete / ignore.
good to see you back!

Once in, they go and change the contact information and authentication number to their own, bippity boppity boop, you'd be sitting in poop.

This is why you ALWAYS contact a company that has apparently contacted you through an unrelated channel, even if the link in the email is (or looks) genuine. You should have contacted Google through a different channel, this is the way to stop phishing: never click on any link in an email and never reply to that email directly. The best advice I can give anyone is having a good head on their shoulders and NEVER do conversations with "companies" that you haven't initiated. A detail I think you've missed here - the scammer did not spoof a Google email address. They sent you a message on Google Chat, and Google Chat then sent you an automated notification email. The email itself was actually 100% legitimate, as it was simply Google themselves notifying you that you'd received a message.
I think the reason why it comes from a google.com email address is because it's an automated Google notification telling you that you have a new Google Chat message.

Thank you Jim for sharing all of this.  This is a good reminder to remain vigilant about always back-end verifying who you are talking to, especially about critical movements  I'm not in tech;  the phishing-test e-mails that the global corporation I work for sends out are so rudimentary and obvious.  An e-mail from someone I've never met from a company I've never heard of asking me to review a docu-sign file and all you have to do it hover the links to see it is obviously nonsense.  This particular scam has a lot more layers.  Good to know.  Thanks!
This would all be solved if YouTube had any point of contact, like a phone number you can call to get creator support. I call my bank to confirm whether or not it was really them who sent me an Email sometimes. I have had a scam Email like that before, saying my bank required some info from me. The give away that time was that the scammer used the wrong bank... I suppose they just used a random bank, that a decent fraction of people receiving that scam mail will actually have. All I can tell you is that I'm not doing anything until I've spoken to a person. I'm never sending a family member money, until I've called them and confirmed it's really them asking me to send them money. Always confirm before doing anything that seems irreversible, like removing or sending anything or giving any info.  Odds are you get some Indian guy on the phone.

"We will permanently suspend your YouTube account" sus. Scammers are so aggressive (and overly 'to the point') when delivering a scare consequence. The fact it's written so plainly, rather than in a corporate way, and not outright framed in some placating way is a massive redflag tho.  I know that the actual support people will vary in their ability to deliver a corporate presence, but the kinda stuff you'd expect would have commonality enough to be pasted becomes so predictably stale and focused on being pleasing or placating that it's like a +1 at stonewalling poor imitators.

An extremely minor note‚Ä¶  When you were surprised the scammer hadn‚Äôt heard of ‚Äú2SA‚Äù, I was not. Just a few moments earlier I‚Äôd had to look up what ‚Äú2SA‚Äù was, despite my having had what I thought was almost exclusively referred to as ‚Äú2FA‚Äù active on dozens of logins for many years.  I suspected from the context that ‚Äú2SA‚Äù was maybe referring to some kind of two-factor auth mechanism but wasn‚Äôt sure. I‚Äôd genuinely never heard of 2FA referred to as 2SA- is that nomenclature particular to youtube? If not then it‚Äôs probably no surprise that he didn‚Äôt understand- if you‚Äôd asked me about something called ‚Äú2SA‚Äù I almost certainly, despite being absolutely familiar with the concept, would have responded intentionally ambiguously, e.g. ‚Äú2SA?‚Äù.

Hey Jim, I just wanted to commend the absolute courage it must've taken to admit that you were scammed; especially as a Youtuber who specialises in outing scammers. I've been watching your videos for a long time and I thoroughly believed that I would never get scammed. And then I did.  The deep amount of shame I felt afterwards was one of the lowest points in my life.  All it takes is a lapse of judgement to get scammed, I've learnt that now.  I hope others are able to take away that if someone like Jim Browning is able to get scammed that potentially anyone can.
BTW, nobody try to DDoS (or other malicious acts) against that IP that was revealed. It is quite likely to belong to someone else now.  IP allocation from an Internet Service Provider often changes, especially if the current user disconnects their modem out of frustration of a malfunctioning connection.

coincidence can really get you tricked by scammers.  The day after I came out of hospital I recieved a text starting with "Dear Paitent"  it was asking to check a website to see if I have visited the areas they listed that have just gone under the title as "Tier 2" for covid outbreak and "contact the hospital" not stating what hospital. That was the first thing that thought was a bit suss, as I usually would gt msgs direct rom the hospital I had just been to. I never clicked the link as I never went anywhere and have no life, so I was not concerned, but  at first I did think it was official.   After checking the number it came from I saw the number was well known as a scam number. When I manually looked for the link dhhs.gov.vic.au   a real government website, but the page on that site does not exist, but it was going to a government address, not a mirrored site. Dunno how they did it, but thi is the first time not having a life being stuck at home helped.

14:26 A "no, u" moment right here. Well-played.
We love you Jim! We are glad you are back!!
Jim, just be careful not to rely on the 2SA too much as it can also be comprised. Earlier this month my Steam account (which had the Steam Guard's 2FA activated on it) was compromised. A nifty little trick where unsuspectingly a person in your friend list (compromised account) messages you (scammer disguising himself as your friend) and asks you to "please vote for him/a friend  for an E-sport competition" and that it wouldn't take too long.   This has been quite popular over the years and I thought nothing of it, I've done it before, for different competitions. So I clicked the link and it seemed legit, with a steam log in page I didn't pay too much attention to. Without thinking, I logged in and it even asked for my 2FA. When I put the 2FA In, it gave me a log in error. After another failed attempt I kindly apologised to my "friend" saying sorry wish I could help but it's not working. He did not respond and I ignored the whole thing.   A couple of weeks later I'm minding my own business next to my pc when I start getting a phone call from my friend asking what the hell is going on? Apparently the hacker was live on my steam account, messaging him as well as all my online friends with the same "please support my friend in this competition" script and it suddenly hit me, I flashed back a couple of weeks ago... I've been compromised!   Long story short, the hacker managed to pass on the viral message to most of those online on my friend list and blocked them so that to make it difficult for me to save them from visiting the phising website. The hacker also went into my Dota 2 account within stream's market place and traded all my market items to random hacker-accounts (in order to sell them for $$), so basically he emptied my account and made it impossible for me to "report" all with ease. Mind you, Steam has a NO-Return policy to returning scammed items back.   How did he bypass the 2FA? I thought. After hours of changing my passwords, completely removing my steam guard and resetting everything, running malware and virus checks, contacting steam support for help on how the heck this hacker managed to bypass the very important 2FA step and how I was never notified when he attempted to log in. It turned out that when I put my 2FA in along with my account user name and password, the hacker was able to put a Steam API key (a perfectly legal tool, but dangerous in the wrong hands) into my steam account (look it up, it's scary what it's capable of), which can manipulate the way the compromised user's Steam Guard reacts to certain login conditions; thereby catering to the hacker's needs to successfully and silently log in without my knowledge.   I immediately found the steam Api key on my steam account (Steam don't make that account section easy to find..) and deleted it from my account. I changed all my passwords again and any other related account passwords in case. I reset my steam guard once more. I thought maybe a 2FA Process using phone number instead of Steam Guard would be better, but I think with this steam API key it really does not matter what 2FA method you use. If anyone knows more about what exactly this steam API key is and how it can be maliciously manipulated, please educate me.   Unfortunately, he got through to a few other people on my list and some of them were also hacked. It's still ongoing! Steam really need to sort this issue out. Of course it was my fault. I was in a rush and paid no second thought to what I was doing.   Never in my life did I think I'd get hacked. It's not a nice feeling - AT ALL. I was practically robbed! and I was made to feel used. This hacker is smart, he left no traces and created multiple accounts in order to keep his viral phishing messages circulating. Some accounts are worth $1000's! So it's no surprise that these horrible people would love to get their hands on them.   Just my experience, hope it helps.
well the same issue hapenned to me I mean almost similar. I swapped phones and next day my Nicehash account was hacked and 272$ in air. I was trapped by a similar scam which got my email and password. as i had swapped phones 2fa was down. and boom.

I got scammed on steam and lost my account for a couple of hours. It was very well organised. Someone was selling an in-game item which he said was worth AU$1000. That I had supposedly bought but the finds didn't appear in his account. I tried to help him before he directed me to a steam support assistant. He told me to tell the support team what was happening. However, it was the same guy or his friend. They went through a prosses to "investigate my account" This required me to sign out on all devices and give him my email. I ensured to ask they he was real. I was being stupid and what we was really doing was resetting my account and changing the email connected to it and I gave him the 2SA code without thinking. I then tried to relog in to my account and it said that there were no accounts associated with that account. Long story short, I filed a report and gave as much evidence that I owned the account as I could. The next day I could log back in. Because I am in Australia and the steam support is in America they fixed it through the night. Once I lived in I enabled every security feature I could and moved the account to a new email. I reported him on steam. Thanks to steam for the assistance. Absolute legends!
moral of the story: YOU DON'T ^&#$ WITH JIM BROWNING

Not gonna lie, I still don't understand how you took the bait. I get that complacency is a thing, but that initial email was still pretty obviously  a scam.   My rule is that when receiving an email from somebody like YouTube, the contents should be clearly automated(no errors whatsoever, no strange word choices, not particularly specific, etc). If it is not automated and I was not anticipating contact, it is immediately written off as a scam.   I'm not trying to be an asshole because it really is a terrible situation. It's just that somebody so well-versed in this sort of thing should not have fallen for this of all things.

So the best thing to do is still, to stop, wait, think and act.  It seems like that is the takeaway from all the scams i have seen on YouTube.  Stop, wait, think, confer with a secondary source and then act.  Even though when you're livelyhood is on the line you're not always able to take a step back. And that are the circumstances you and I will get scammed in. When we're in a hurry. When we fear for our livelyhood/live. When loved ones are at risk. Etc. Emotional distress is a powerful tool leveraged by scammers.

It's amazing that you made this video, it will help so many other people avoid this scam. Not that it matters, but your understanding of the email itself wasn't quite on the money. The email is genuinely sent from Google, it's just a notification email that lets you know someone has sent you a message on the Google Chat app. It's like getting an email from Facebook that lets you know you have an unread message in Facebook Messenger. Completely legit email, the scammer hasn't "hacked" into Google Chat and gained access to the "from address". There's been similar scams in the past that made use of Google Docs notification emails, but the scammers cannot send literally anything from a genuine google.com email address, they are just triggering legitimate notification emails in a sneaky way.

Welp, I've done cyber sec as part of my degree and got hooked by a phishing attempt because of timing. Something was wrong with my card address and I couldn't link Amazon Prime with Twitch Prime, and I had emailed Amazon about it. 2 days later I got a phishing email from "Amazon" asking for my card details and I didn't check twice since obviously I had just asked them for some help with the card details(something was not working directly from the site). Sometimes you can just get caught by sheer bad luck and shitty timing. Also something I was never expecting to happen to me, I don't even click on http links and generally am very aware of risks, but it can absolutely happen to literally anyone
Just yesterday I was helping my mother do some internet/tv stuff. I ended up with a prompt on a website to call Amazon to complete my task. Only it wasn't Amazon... it was a number to a scam call center who was pretending to be Amazon. Luckily, because I watch your videos and other scambaiters, I was able to recognize a suspicious "sales" pitch and disconnect the call. I felt kind of stupid for the rest of the evening because I found that the reason I got to that scam website and scam phone number was because I clicked on an ad link instead of the Amazon link. The ONLY reason I didn't fall for it was because I follow Jim Browning and a few other scambaiters.   So thank you for everything. And thank you for posting this video. If Jim Browning can make a mistake, I don't feel so stupid for almost falling for scam. Keep up the good work.

Did he have verification before?
Don't ever click links in emails, no matter what! Even ones you're 100% sure are legit. Even ones that technically ARE legit like this case. If a website tells you there's an issue and gives you a support link, DO NOT CLICK THE LINK. Go to support yourself and verify whatever the email may be claiming.

Well, this is story all about how...
Number 1 to look out for: If you are being rushed to do something serious, then you have to literally check and double check everything. Breathe for a moment, and try to not get pressured by what someone has sent to you. "Scammers like to involve a sense of fear or urgency as a tactic to bully you into action, so you don‚Äôt have time to ask for help or think things through." While everything may seem legit at a first glance, it won't be a waste to take a second glance at it. But as Jim Browning has said, anyone can get scammed. Stay safe everyone out there.

Holy Cow! If they can scam you, they can scam anybody. I was almost taken by a scammer on Facebook Messenger. They managed to hack a friend's facebook account and used it to steer me into a Publisher's Clearinghouse scam. They managed to get some persanal information out of me before they made the mistake of sticking their hand out for a "Processing Fee". That was when I woke up and shut them down. Right after that, I went through and changed all my passwords and activated two-factor authentication wherever it is possible. I also removed credit card information from all my on-line accounts. It makes for more of a hassle when shopping on-line, but there haven't been any fraudulent charges. I also checked my credit history and made sure that nobody is applying for credit in my name. Identity theft is a terrible thing. Like Atomic Shrimp says, "you know, the kind of information you should never give to a stranger on the Internet."

Not addressing you by your name on record is typically a tell-tale sign of a scam to me. The only time I nearly fell for a scam was when one email attempted to blackmail me saying they had files on me, then spoofed my own email to try and prove it. I quickly learned they could spoof my email address though. I'm not saying this to sound superior to anyone, everyone should just be aware of the signs, not addressing you correctly by name and usually just using a greeting or your email address "Hi example@outlook.com" it's usually a scam.

The very basic preventative measure that is 100% guaranteed to make sure nobody gets scammed like this is dead simple.  If you receive an e-mail from Amazon, your bank, Paypal, even youtube you always reply it by opening up a browser window, typing the relevant company, finding their support e-mail and contacting them back through that.  If there is a real issue, you have a 100% chance of resolving it, if its a scam there is 0% chance of being scammed.

Thank you for sharing your story, Jim, and glad you're back.
Re the beginning of the video, this seems more than a scammer. It seems like a spear phishing attack, potentially with some extra assistance.  1) The person who crafted this has done research om YouTube creaters to find an effective fear trigger specifically for YouTubers (loss of ad revenue), and figured out the normal tells (bad spelling, bad domains, etc). The random capitals and the lack of spacing just before the very last link would only be spotted by very close attention. Overall, the message is mostly coherent with its premise, however.  2) I think it's extremely unlikely that it was coincidence you had switched to a new phone when they struck. I would be looking for malware on the old device and changing all my account passwords (and making sure authenticator-based MFA is on, at minimum) in case something was monitoring.  3) Jim Browning would be a prime target for scammers to enlist other 'help' to carry out a more sophisticated attack. 4) The attackers had clearly done research to figure out the loopholes in Google's process for replacing and deleting channels, and crafted a convincing chat script for it.
"I sent a Grabify link"  *I'll initiate a counter-hack*

So he sends you a screenshot saying he made 16k with stolen channels, in 28 days, but then says he needs money and asks you to send him money.   Totally a fake screenshot. He ain't making jack. 16k a month would set me up nicely.
Thank you for this video, it helps to know these scams/phishes for my personal protection against them.  That initial e-mail had two red flags that I would have done a runaround and contacted YouTube through a separate means than directly from the email.  One flag: Tone of email. Scam/phishing emails use something scary and ask to 'click here'. Second flag: Consistency failure. They ask you to click 'Try Chat', but the button is labeled 'Open in Google Chat'.   That said, no scam/phishing email I have dealt with recently have passed the domain test check in the From field like this would have.
If he made that much he would not ask for $100.

Glad your back !!
Yeah, I had a similar thing happen recently that also almost caught me out through coincidence.  A USPS phishing email that looked like it actually came from them.  The coincidence was I was expecting a package at some point from family from the states.  But because my mom had not actually advised me that she had shipped anything yet, which was unusual and sooner than anticipated, I did my usual checks.  Sender email address did actually appear to be from USPS (I also am in the habit of hovering over every link and email address to confirm "real" senders and link targets).  Couldn't get a hold of my mom to confirm she had actually sent something.  Refused to click link in email because I couldn't get confirmation from family, but did manually check tracking number on USPS website, and sure enough it brought up a real package.  Everything up to that point was checking out, but it fell apart from there.  Yes it was a real package shipped from the US, but was shipped to a completely different country AND was over a year out of date.  It was only at that point I was sure it was a phishing email.  I know I feel like I was almost caught out, but that was only because they had passed my usual first, second, and third tier checks.  I know enough about the tree/forest relationship to recognize the correct order that domains should be listed, so I was really surprised to see the correct structure in the sender information.  Couldn't even believe the tracking number was real.  It was only after I scrutinized the actual tracking record that I was able to confirm that it wasn't real.  And if I hadn't actually been expecting a package from the states at that particular time I would've been a lot more wary of that particular email.  Thankfully I didn't get caught out because I decided not to click anything until I could get my mom to confirm that she had actually shipped a package.  I was impressed they had gotten that far past my usual checks.  It was definitely a first.  But also a bit scared realizing I'm going to have to up my game and checks to keep myself and family/friends safe in the future if it's going to be that hard to spot a fake in the future.  So far, that email was one in a million.  But I would be stupid to assume that it'll stay that way.  Glad to see you caught it in time Jim and were able to recover from it.  But yeah, even the most diligent and technically aware of us can be caught out if enough of the cards are not in our favor.  No shame in it.  It happens.
Glad you're back! Don't be too hard on yourself. Nobody is above being victimized. These scammers are wily as serpents. The more we crack down on their crimes, the more resourceful they will have to become to survive.

Much of Northern Syria's internet is a series of radio/microwave relays that are essentially beamed over the border from Turkey. Very few towns outside of Damascus would have access to a Syrian ISP, so a lot of small towns instead use single wifi networks tied into this (illegitimate) Turkish border system. Many Syrians would likely be using actual Turkish IP addresses because of this, so I can well believe this guy was in Syria.

Hey Jim, glad to see you're back.  I have an odd one for you, you might want to look into it. I wish I had actual data to provide, but all I have is a story.  The other week my phone lit up asking me "was this you". Google two-step had caught someone in "Paris TX" trying to log into my account on a Chromebook. I've never owned a Chromebook, so this was obviously a compromise. I denied it, and waited for another notification to see if I needed to change my password.  The notification popped up, three times back-to-back. I quickly selected "secure your account", and changed my password.  Here's where things get scary... I entered an old password, as per instructed by the password changing steps. I then entered a new password, and the moment I tried to confirm the new password, the screen backpedaled, and I was met with "You have been signed out, please enter your password to sign back in".  ...I panicked a bit, and entered my new password. Didn't work. Old password...didn't work neither.   Luckily...I am a smart boy. I have google logged in on my PC, I pulled up the security settings from there, went into the list of devices that are approved for my account, and removed everyone of them from the list except the PC I was on. I then changed my password, and redid my two-step authentication and backup codes for good measure.  I then did a couple of scans, and they turned up nothing. I decided, reluctantly, to reset my phone. The problem hasn't happened since. I think this is definitely worth looking into. I suspect a bot program was doing this, but how is the big question. I sent what little information I had to the google support team so they could double check their securities, and seeing your video made me feel I should at least share the story with you.

Someone getting the drop on Jim Browning? I never thought I'd see the day. It indeed proves that it can happen to the best of us.  Phase one of the scam was really well done. Edit: Why are all the spambots replying to my comment as if I was Jim?
Turkey is very well known for companies who scam people in Germany over the phone. It's mostly about magazine subscriptions and lottery tickets. They start with a big lie that goes like: "Do you want your subscription [which does not actually exist] to continue for a year or should we cancel after 3 month?" If you tell them to cancel, which they will press you on, they start a recording and ask for bank details, name etc. to prove a telemarketing contract. The victims are mostly old people.
That Google Form is devious. It says ‚ÄúThis form was created inside Google.‚Äù This is a really neat trick. He has a Google Workspace account with the name ‚ÄúGoogle‚Äù so that it appears like the Google Form was from Google proper. If you setup a Google Workspace account with an organization name, the footer normally says the org name. This is supposed to be a trust system so you know you‚Äôre communicating with a legitimate Google Workspace org, like your company. But he used that to act as another trust layer. It‚Äôs really interesting.

"what do you mean by real support?"....."I'm youtube" I think that could be the greatest thing I've ever read
What the scammer do is just asking you to move your main channel to brand channel, this is usually used by people who sell channel to another person (I do this couple times), basically you never lost or delete your channel. People can't find your channel because you now have new 'URL' in your new brand channel, and because it's new, it's not crawled by google yet.   And why you see all your video gone because when you move your channel to brand channel, you should login to the brand channel and your channel is there (only your comment in every of your video got deleted, because it can't be transferred).  I think he do this just to make the victim's think that he really got an access to your channel. and that's why the victim feel that they should fill the form , because they're in pressure losing the channel. About the screenshot, the RPM is about $1.3, so it's from some gaming channel I guess. It has low RPM. average RPM is about $3 (that means you get $3000 per 1mio views). If he got that screenshot from some video, it's probably from gaming channel talking about how much did he got from youtube.  And yes, there's no way for him to get that revenue, when some 'big youtuber' lost their channel, they will directly contact youtube, and usually youtube recover their channel in days. so there's no way for him to have time to wait 2 months (since youtube pay you 20 days later from the running month) to change the adsense (so the money goes to his adsense acc), and then receive the money. so him talking about he got xx million dollars is bullshit, especially when he ask you $100.
I initially thought "Wow! The audacity of this guy" but then realised he had absolutely no idea who you were and what it is you do. It really does prove that NOBODY is immune from these parasites. All it takes is for a lucky coincidence and a momentary lapse of concentration/clarity. Glad to see you back up & running.

It was wild the fact that I experienced the confusion as it was happening. Anyway, good to have you back and on to bingeing some more.

Sadly, my Facebook account got compromised earlier this year. The person used my account to buy Facebook ads, and within no time at all, some spam detection system noticed the weird activity and suspended my account, and notified me that it maybe got compromised. I went through all the steps to re-acquire the account and prove my identity, but Facebook never un-suspended my account. :-(  The worst part is they don't actually let you download your data once it gets suspended. They actually have a button to let you do that on the account suspension page, but the button doesn't work. And there's no such thing as a Facebook support team. That's 8 years of photos and memories gone.

If they were targeting you directly (spear phishing) the 2FA may not have saved you if via SMS. A coordinated SIM swap attack would have gotten them the ability to 2FA via SMS. Phone companies have next to no account security and will happily move your number to a new SIM with very few easy questions. SIM swaps are very common attacks.

I'm just going to throw this out there: a good indication that this was a phishing attack is the fact that the sender only said "Hi". Normally a legit sender would know the name of the recipient, while a general greeting would be a scam. Occasionally scammers may know your name (being associated with your email address) from previous security breaches, so don't fall for that either.

There's a similar scam on Steam, it starts with one of your friends who's already fallen for it messaging you saying they "accidentally reported you for duped items" if they get a response they give you a link to one of the scammer's profiles who's posing as a steam admin, any real admin will have a badge on their profile, these guys don't. They'll then proceed to try to get all of your account details to login, after they've hijacked your account they'll attempt the same thing with your friends on your friends list as well as taking any valuable items in your backpack. They'll try to use fear of account deletion to ensure cooperation and if they don't get it they just stop talking to you and/or try to get rid of the account if they have enough access, please don't fall for this one like I did.

Sometimes I see people post comments on scam videos saying things like "How could anyone be stupid enough to fall for that?" or "If you fall for that scam you deserve it" and it gets me irritated. Maybe you wouldn't fall for that particular scam, but no one is an expert in everything, and no one is vigilant all the time, and there's someone out there who could say just the right thing at the right time to fool you. And when that happens, you shouldn't feel ashamed to talk about. Your experience can help others from falling for the same scam.

Sorry. We live in a world of scammers, not just in your world.
I previously heard of something similar that happened to a small Youtuber called Suris. He talked about it on a video where he says that those channels get deleted so that content farms can use them. The content farms don't want to waste time monetizing a channel from the ground up, so what they do is steal channels that already have monetization and subscribers and  leverage those channels' algorithmic reach, siphoning off the profits as well. Usually it's small channels like Suris', but, as this indicates, sometimes they catch bigger fish as well. Like this one. Only this one, like Suris, got away from them - thankfully. Here's the Suris video on a similar topic:               https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iD25VvFEza4

Google has quite the monopoly on email. So much so that, until half a year or so ago, any mail sent from a google server was automatically authenticated on google's mailservers. This meant that anyone could sign up for a "Google G-suite" account, pay a couple of bucks and be authenticated when sending mails to any gmail account, almost no matter the from-address. Thankfully they closed that "loop-hole". Having hosted a couple of mailservers myself, I'm quite furiated by how so-so their approach is to emails and security.

THE LEYEND IS BACK!!!!
Welcome back Jim!  I'm extremely impressed by the way you handled this situation. As someone who works with computer users that range from technically incompetent, to very skilled, I can tell you that a lot of them will try to cover it up when they have compromised the security in some way. Some will even end up waiting until it escalates, and then they are forced to admit what they did before it blows up completely. However I have yet to experience a situation where this is done out of malice. The fact is that they are embarrassed, ashamed, afraid that they will lose their job, etc.  You could easily have covered this up by claiming that you were fed up, and didn't want to do the YouTube thing anymore. However you went the opposite route by telling everyone what had happened, and thus turning a crappy situation into a valuable teaching moment. Some people have commented (on different platforms) that you should delete the channel because no one would take your advice after this, but they obviously don't understand how much this proves the points you have been making all the time:  1. I have never heard you trying to fault the victims of scams. They do the best they can based on their situation, and skill.  2. The scammers make a living by trying to steal from people, and a lot of them are very good at what they do. None of us can scrutinize every single encounter we have with others, so if the scam is good enough, and the circumstances are right, we will all fall for it unless we are very lucky.  3. Recognizing/admitting that you have been scammed can be painful, and make you feel stupid, but it is important as it can prevent others from being scammed. By being so humble, and honest, you are making it easier for others to accept that being fooled by someone isn't as shameful as they might have thought.  Kudos to you for being a great role model Jim! We can all learn from your example. Good to have you back. üôÇ
Welcome back lol

That's not the "from" address tho, thats the google chat notification service address ... which is the entire trick. But it's standard for messaging platform notifications, as there isn't really another way to do it. The main issue here was that they were able to create a google account with a username of "YouTube Support" without immediately getting flagged. ... Also the Google Chat notification does look alot like an email, rather than a chat notification, since it's simple and "google" styled.

Apparently I never had to resubscribe but this just goes to show you can never be too careful with these things. I've even gotten emails that I almost fell for until I stepped back and took a closer took at them to realize they were fake. One thing I always do is to NEVER click on links in the emails and go to the real site to check if what the email says is true as I can be sure the real site will let me know if anything is wrong if indeed something is. If you aren't seeing any messages on the site indicating a problem that should be a big red flag that the email might not be legit.

When I'm faced with one of these situations, I have a fool-proof way of checking the validity of whoever might be reaching out to me. Just don't reply for am hour or two (after the first reply, of course). If they reach out twice in a row, it's definitely a scam. Official YouTube has no reason to want you to fix your account so badly they text more than once. It's just too desperate and then it becomes so very obvious. Scammers can't get around this, either, since this is their method of income.

Girlfriend has a 200k Youtube channel and a Russian hacker managed to hack into her account, WITH 2FA ON, and could live stream something about a crypto scam, so the channel got deleted from youtube. The email address may always be spoofed, but there are ways to check: In gmail, click the "show original" option and check that both SPF and DKIM checks "PASS", also look out for suspicious "reply to" fields, that make sure you don't reply to the spoofed address, since the scammer doesn't actually control it.  ThioJoe made a great video about this.

That scammer said something that raised a Red Flag.  He asked for money so that he could leave the scamming business.  Recently I've noticed some YouTube channels that might be "posing" as Scam Baiting channels, but might in fact be actual scammers.  They 'interview' scammers and try to gain viewer sympathy for the scammer's economic situation, so they ask viewers to donate money so that the scammer can quit scamming and lead an honest, upright life.  But one thing I know for certain, once a scammer, always a scammer.  So I'm super suspicious of those channels that ask for money to 'rescue' the scammers from a life of thieving.  I hope no one is dumb enough to fall for that obvious ruse.

I think the syrian guy only knew about the whole ''procedure'' to move a channel to another, because he tried that on his own channel once, and figured out : he could make a scam out of this.  I can imagine, he indeed destroyed few big channels that way (i dont think he ''owns'' it, like he said ... probably he wanted to say : he pwned those big million-subscriber-channels ).  And i can imagine: someone who lose a channel that big , will indeed ready to pay 100 Dollars to regain his channel. And because he knew the exact youtube-procedure of ''moving a channel'' it sounded convincing - he got those 100 Dollars, but the Youtuber didnt got his channel back.  This video is a big reminder : that not everything is a matter of ''who is smarter'' . I am sure, Jim is smarter than this ''turkey/syria'' guy , but as Jim said correctly : the circumstances helped the scammer a lot. This video shows, how much security the internet needs - because if those security isnt established , than with the right circumstances everyone can be scammed (and thats really scary).
