Scary stuff Jim!! BUT A PERFECT LESSON FOR ALL OF US!! You nailed it, it's timing and coincidence that lead to a lot of their successes, and thru simple mathematics and the law of averages they WILL SUCCEED in connecting with people at precisely the right time, so much so, that Jim freakin' Browning nearly fell for one!! Remember folks, DO NOT PANIC, a lot of these scams are based on panic, and getting you to react, to rush to solve the problem, and to get you so flustered and confused, all you want to do is make sure you're secure again.... TAKE YOUR TIME, ground yourself, if something HAS happened and whatever you're confronted with isn't a scam, then it's already happened, ground yourself, focus and make sure you're paying attention.... The golden rule with administration/support is that you contact them, you don't allow them to contact you.  If you think there might be a problem with your account, or someone claiming to be support or administration tries to contact you, go to the service provider's website and find the contact details of their actual support team and ask them if there's a problem...

Really glad that you're back in action!  I don't blame you for falling for it initially, that @google.com is tricksy, false.
I wrote on your original tweet to report the domain so I'm happy that it didn't get ignored. I can say without a doubt that DH is looking into the issue considering at least 13 people to my knowledge clicked on the link and a few more on Reddit. support-youtube, as mentioned at around 8:28 in the video, is another domain that should be reported (both to their registrar Bigrock and to DigitalOcean who is hosting their SMTP server), support-youtub should also be reported to Google Domains. Also important to note is that this is legally fraud (they are (1) intentionally (2) misrepresenting (3) a material fact known to the defendant (they weren‚Äôt YouTube Support) (4) with the intention to deprive a person of property or other injuries (transferring someone's account to profit from ad revenue), this verbiage comes from the California civil code but applies here anyway) and it should be reported to the UNHCR via email.  This is most definitely, based on the fact support-youtube is registered by BigRock (the biggest Indian registrar), an international scam and the guy in the video is responsible for a small yet powerful part of it.  Stay safe, everyone!

I got hacked within days of you, for context I'm in my 20s, have always been into amateur security, haven't had a virus since I was maybe.. 12? I haven't even seen a virus popup in a good 5+ years. I always use 2FA, I always use a VPN, I always have virus scanner on. Even through all that; Someone was able to access my google account, the password chain, and then gain passwords to all my accounts, (Banking, Paypal, Social media, etc.). It was a real hassle for a few days, but it was quickly fixed with some patience and determination.  I will never scoff at my grandparents or parents again if they get hacked. These methods are getting scary, and if someone like Jim can get hacked, it's a real wakeup call on another level. I have a lot left to learn about security. Thank you so much Jim. I'm a big fan.

A little known fact of YouTube is YOU CANNOT CONTACT YOUTUBE DIRECTLY. If YouTube genuinely threatens your account, they will do so via an e-mail and replying directly to the e-mail is the only way to respond. The classic advice of "contact the sender directly outside the e-mail chain" is IMPOSSIBLE with YouTube. So YouTube, by having awful customer service, have enabled a scam like this to be very convincing.

wow impressive proof that anyone can be scammed, so be carefull and wb Jim!
This is a good lesson, and it doesn't only happen on youtube. My mom passed away in 2018, and my dad followed her in 2019 (she was 90 and he was 91, a pretty good run in anybodies book). While my brothers and I were dealing with the estate I was tasked with selling dad's Jaguar and his vintage race car. I first posted the race car in the classified sections of the vintage race clubs dad belonged to.  I got a quick email hit from a guy that was really interested, and was ready to send the money sight unseen. Red flag 1. He had some grammar problems, but that's not unusual in today's society, but it did tug at the back of my mind. Red flag 2. Since my brother is the executor I had the "buyer" send the check to him. The "buyer" sent me a text message to see if we had gotten it. I called my brother and he said he had gotten it, but it was for $12,000 instead of the agreed upon $10,000. I texted the "buyer" and asked about the extra 2 grand and he said that was to be used to pay the transport company. I pointed out that the buyer pays the transporter. He said it was the only they (the transport company) would agree to pick up the car. Red flag 3. I told my brother about the arrangement and mentioned  that "I hope this isn't a scam". He felt it was okay and he just wanted to get the car sold.  My short hairs were standing up by now so I looked at the phone number on the text message and saw it began with a 15 prefix. I threw that into google and found that that number was associated with numbers in either Glasgow or Jaipur, India (guess which one I figured it was!). I then did a google search on the name in the emails and found he'd been hitting other vintage car sites (one was a Jeep lovers forum and another was a Ford Model T site). I called my brother and told him not to send the money, but I was about 30 minutes too late. So we were out $2k.  I placed ads on RacingJunk.com and immediately got texts from four different people, all using numbers with the 15 prefix. They all had the same MO (I mean word for word, like they had the same script in front of them). I strung them along while I talked with legit buyers, and, when I said to not send additional money because I wouldn't pay the shipper, all but one dropped out. After the initial contact they switched to a US number to continue the text conversation (Atlanta, GA; Fernly, NV; Concord, CA, etc.), the one that I had hooked good then switched to a Bakersfield, CA number and sent me a check with the extra $2k. The check was written from a lighting installation company in St. Louis, MO and was fedexed from a company in Tucson, AZ. I told him I wouldn't pay the shipper and what did he want me to do with the $2k. He then told me to get a cashiers check and send it to a woman in upstate New York. That's the point I got tired of playing with him (the car had sold two weeks before this) and told him how his operation worked, and that he should talk to the people in the cubicles on either side of him because they were all trying to hook the same fish. I had also contacted the FBI and my local Sheriffs Dept. and they had started case numbers on it. He of course accused me of trying to steal his money ("no I'm not because you and I both know the check is worthless") and that he had a cousin who was a senior investigator for the Central Bureau of Federal Investigations, and he could call him and have me arrested, what did I want him to do. I told him he'd better call his cousin and while he was talking to him have him look up Case Number 21-043. I kind of miss him!  If you made it this far, and haven't done it yet, throw a like on Jim's video and stay alert.
Finaly a new video. Lets gooo! I love your videos man.

Jim, you are mistaken about the legitimacy of that Google message you received. Hence your advice at the end is not helpful if not counter-productive. The message _was_ legitimate and Google can't do much if anything about it. It's like your phone company sending you a message that you received a phone call. This is by all means legitimate no matter who called. Only at Google Chat one can actually verify (as you pointed out) who one is talking too.

This pissed a lot of people off, you might remember Bob and his tank in the comments? I finally gave up last year and did exactly what Jim did in the video and merge the accounts, and it deleted EVERYTHING. Even my playlists, with thousands of videos saved. The worst part? Welcome back ü§ó
You got suckered in because you missed the first clue -- how upset you were that there was a problem.  You went straight to your (fantastic) logical mind of 'what could have plausibly caused the (alleged) problem (the coincidental phone change)', then on to 'how you can quickly solve this problem to get back all of your years of fantastic efforts.'  Take time to notice your feeling of being upset, anxious, or whatever.  That's where scammers succeed and people overlook the scammer's details that would show you that they're lying.  Give yourself huge kudos for (unconsciously?) spotting all the other untruths even as you were calming down, making it easier to see the scammer's untruths, which you do so wonderfully and in great detail for us on a regular basis.  Glad you're back!!  Thank you for everything you do!!!

yeah like you said at the end, anyone can fall for a scam. Sometimes it's just the perfect storm of circumstance that can put you in a vulnerable mindset. You might think you know every trick in the book, but if someone manages to get you by surprise and legitimately make you scared or worried, suddenly you're willing to do anything to resolve the situation.

Everyone in the comments is using this to say ‚Äúanyone can fall for scams!‚Äù. Uh, no, either the vid itself was faked with the intention of spreading that message (unlikely), or it just means some people aren‚Äôt as smart as they first seem. I can understand children, elderly and people with mental disabilities falling for scams, but if you‚Äôre none of the prior and you have a fully functioning brain, these kinda things don‚Äôt happen, not unless the scammers themselves are clever (which is a definite minority, but they do exist). Scamming is just a test of technological intelligence and common sense, nothing more. The way I personally see it, Jim either let down his guard for some reason or other, or the scammer was one of the aforementioned clever ones.  This comment isn‚Äôt designed to spark a big argument, i‚Äôm simply stating my opinion (based on logic). If you disagree, that‚Äôs completely fine, you can believe what you want to. As for at Jim directly (although it‚Äôs very unlikely you‚Äôll see this comment), i‚Äôm not just a hater or anything, been watching these videos for a while now and I truly feel you‚Äôre doing a good job, especially with the major stuff such as the shutting down call centres, spreading awareness and setting anti-scammer precedents. It just seems like you let your guard down above all else, but that‚Äôs just my theory on the matter
